title: Wuthering Heights

text: from the gate to the Grange is two miles; I believe I managed to make
title: Wuthering Heights

text: it four, what with losing myself among the trees, and sinking up to the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: neck in snow: a predicament which only those who have experienced it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: can appreciate. At any rate, whatever were my wanderings, the clock
title: Wuthering Heights

text: chimed twelve as I entered the house; and that gave exactly an hour for
title: Wuthering Heights

text: every mile of the usual way from Wuthering Heights.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: My human fixture and her satellites rushed to welcome me; exclaiming,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: tumultuously, they had completely given me up: everybody conjectured
title: Wuthering Heights

text: that I perished last night; and they were wondering how they must set
title: Wuthering Heights

text: about the search for my remains. I bid them be quiet, now that they saw
title: Wuthering Heights

text: me returned, and, benumbed to my very heart, I dragged upstairs;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: whence, after putting on dry clothes, and pacing to and fro thirty or
title: Wuthering Heights

text: forty minutes, to restore the animal heat, I adjourned to my study,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: feeble as a kitten: almost too much so to enjoy the cheerful fire and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: smoking coffee which the servant had prepared for my refreshment.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Wuthering Heights

text: What vain weather-cocks we are! I, who had determined to hold myself
title: Wuthering Heights

text: independent of all social intercourse, and thanked my stars that, at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: length, I had lighted on a spot where it was next to impracticable—I,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: weak wretch, after maintaining till dusk a struggle with low spirits
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and solitude, was finally compelled to strike my colours; and under
title: Wuthering Heights

text: pretence of gaining information concerning the necessities of my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: establishment, I desired Mrs. Dean, when she brought in supper, to sit
title: Wuthering Heights

text: down while I ate it; hoping sincerely she would prove a regular gossip,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and either rouse me to animation or lull me to sleep by her talk.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “You have lived here a considerable time,” I commenced; “did you not
title: Wuthering Heights

text: say sixteen years?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Eighteen, sir: I came when the mistress was married, to wait on her;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: after she died, the master retained me for his housekeeper.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Indeed.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: There ensued a pause. She was not a gossip, I feared; unless about her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: own affairs, and those could hardly interest me. However, having
title: Wuthering Heights

text: studied for an interval, with a fist on either knee, and a cloud of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: meditation over her ruddy countenance, she ejaculated—“Ah, times are
title: Wuthering Heights

text: greatly changed since then!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Yes,” I remarked, “you’ve seen a good many alterations, I suppose?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I have: and troubles too,” she said.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Oh, I’ll turn the talk on my landlord’s family!” I thought to myself.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “A good subject to start! And that pretty girl-widow, I should like to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: know her history: whether she be a native of the country, or, as is
title: Wuthering Heights

text: more probable, an exotic that the surly _indigenae_ will not recognise
title: Wuthering Heights

text: for kin.” With this intention I asked Mrs. Dean why Heathcliff let
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Thrushcross Grange, and preferred living in a situation and residence
title: Wuthering Heights

text: so much inferior. “Is he not rich enough to keep the estate in good
title: Wuthering Heights

text: order?” I inquired.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Rich, sir!” she returned. “He has nobody knows what money, and every
title: Wuthering Heights

text: year it increases. Yes, yes, he’s rich enough to live in a finer house
title: Wuthering Heights

text: than this: but he’s very near—close-handed; and, if he had meant to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: flit to Thrushcross Grange, as soon as he heard of a good tenant he
title: Wuthering Heights

text: could not have borne to miss the chance of getting a few hundreds more.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: It is strange people should be so greedy, when they are alone in the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: world!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “He had a son, it seems?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Yes, he had one—he is dead.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “And that young lady, Mrs. Heathcliff, is his widow?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Yes.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Where did she come from originally?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Why, sir, she is my late master’s daughter: Catherine Linton was her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: maiden name. I nursed her, poor thing! I did wish Mr. Heathcliff would
title: Wuthering Heights

text: remove here, and then we might have been together again.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “What! Catherine Linton?” I exclaimed, astonished. But a minute’s
title: Wuthering Heights

text: reflection convinced me it was not my ghostly Catherine. “Then,” I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: continued, “my predecessor’s name was Linton?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “It was.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “And who is that Earnshaw: Hareton Earnshaw, who lives with Mr.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff? Are they relations?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “No; he is the late Mrs. Linton’s nephew.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “The young lady’s cousin, then?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Yes; and her husband was her cousin also: one on the mother’s, the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: other on the father’s side: Heathcliff married Mr. Linton’s sister.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I see the house at Wuthering Heights has ‘Earnshaw’ carved over the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: front door. Are they an old family?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Very old, sir; and Hareton is the last of them, as our Miss Cathy is
title: Wuthering Heights

text: of us—I mean, of the Lintons. Have you been to Wuthering Heights? I beg
title: Wuthering Heights

text: pardon for asking; but I should like to hear how she is!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Mrs. Heathcliff? she looked very well, and very handsome; yet, I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: think, not very happy.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Oh dear, I don’t wonder! And how did you like the master?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “A rough fellow, rather, Mrs. Dean. Is not that his character?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Rough as a saw-edge, and hard as whinstone! The less you meddle with
title: Wuthering Heights

text: him the better.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “He must have had some ups and downs in life to make him such a churl.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Do you know anything of his history?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “It’s a cuckoo’s, sir—I know all about it: except where he was born,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and who were his parents, and how he got his money at first. And
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Hareton has been cast out like an unfledged dunnock! The unfortunate
title: Wuthering Heights

text: lad is the only one in all this parish that does not guess how he has
title: Wuthering Heights

text: been cheated.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Well, Mrs. Dean, it will be a charitable deed to tell me something of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: my neighbours: I feel I shall not rest if I go to bed; so be good
title: Wuthering Heights

text: enough to sit and chat an hour.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Oh, certainly, sir! I’ll just fetch a little sewing, and then I’ll sit
title: Wuthering Heights

text: as long as you please. But you’ve caught cold: I saw you shivering, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you must have some gruel to drive it out.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: The worthy woman bustled off, and I crouched nearer the fire; my head
title: Wuthering Heights

text: felt hot, and the rest of me chill: moreover, I was excited, almost to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: a pitch of foolishness, through my nerves and brain. This caused me to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: feel, not uncomfortable, but rather fearful (as I am still) of serious
title: Wuthering Heights

text: effects from the incidents of to-day and yesterday. She returned
title: Wuthering Heights

text: presently, bringing a smoking basin and a basket of work; and, having
title: Wuthering Heights

text: placed the former on the hob, drew in her seat, evidently pleased to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: find me so companionable.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Before I came to live here, she commenced—waiting no farther invitation
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to her story—I was almost always at Wuthering Heights; because my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mother had nursed Mr. Hindley Earnshaw, that was Hareton’s father, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I got used to playing with the children: I ran errands too, and helped
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to make hay, and hung about the farm ready for anything that anybody
title: Wuthering Heights

text: would set me to. One fine summer morning—it was the beginning of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: harvest, I remember—Mr. Earnshaw, the old master, came downstairs,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: dressed for a journey; and, after he had told Joseph what was to be
title: Wuthering Heights

text: done during the day, he turned to Hindley, and Cathy, and me—for I sat
title: Wuthering Heights

text: eating my porridge with them—and he said, speaking to his son, “Now, my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bonny man, I’m going to Liverpool to-day, what shall I bring you? You
title: Wuthering Heights

text: may choose what you like: only let it be little, for I shall walk there
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and back: sixty miles each way, that is a long spell!” Hindley named a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fiddle, and then he asked Miss Cathy; she was hardly six years old, but
title: Wuthering Heights

text: she could ride any horse in the stable, and she chose a whip. He did
title: Wuthering Heights

text: not forget me; for he had a kind heart, though he was rather severe
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sometimes. He promised to bring me a pocketful of apples and pears, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: then he kissed his children, said good-bye, and set off.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: It seemed a long while to us all—the three days of his absence—and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: often did little Cathy ask when he would be home. Mrs. Earnshaw
title: Wuthering Heights

text: expected him by supper-time on the third evening, and she put the meal
title: Wuthering Heights

text: off hour after hour; there were no signs of his coming, however, and at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: last the children got tired of running down to the gate to look. Then
title: Wuthering Heights

text: it grew dark; she would have had them to bed, but they begged sadly to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: be allowed to stay up; and, just about eleven o’clock, the door-latch
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was raised quietly, and in stepped the master. He threw himself into a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: chair, laughing and groaning, and bid them all stand off, for he was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: nearly killed—he would not have such another walk for the three
title: Wuthering Heights

text: kingdoms.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “And at the end of it to be flighted to death!” he said, opening his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: great-coat, which he held bundled up in his arms. “See here, wife! I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was never so beaten with anything in my life: but you must e’en take it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: as a gift of God; though it’s as dark almost as if it came from the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: devil.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: We crowded round, and over Miss Cathy’s head I had a peep at a dirty,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: ragged, black-haired child; big enough both to walk and talk: indeed,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: its face looked older than Catherine’s; yet when it was set on its
title: Wuthering Heights

text: feet, it only stared round, and repeated over and over again some
title: Wuthering Heights

text: gibberish that nobody could understand. I was frightened, and Mrs.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Earnshaw was ready to fling it out of doors: she did fly up, asking how
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he could fashion to bring that gipsy brat into the house, when they had
title: Wuthering Heights

text: their own bairns to feed and fend for? What he meant to do with it, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: whether he were mad? The master tried to explain the matter; but he was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: really half dead with fatigue, and all that I could make out, amongst
title: Wuthering Heights

text: her scolding, was a tale of his seeing it starving, and houseless, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: as good as dumb, in the streets of Liverpool, where he picked it up and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: inquired for its owner. Not a soul knew to whom it belonged, he said;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and his money and time being both limited, he thought it better to take
title: Wuthering Heights

text: it home with him at once, than run into vain expenses there: because he
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was determined he would not leave it as he found it. Well, the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: conclusion was, that my mistress grumbled herself calm; and Mr.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Earnshaw told me to wash it, and give it clean things, and let it sleep
title: Wuthering Heights

text: with the children.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Hindley and Cathy contented themselves with looking and listening till
title: Wuthering Heights

text: peace was restored: then, both began searching their father’s pockets
title: Wuthering Heights

text: for the presents he had promised them. The former was a boy of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fourteen, but when he drew out what had been a fiddle, crushed to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: morsels in the great-coat, he blubbered aloud; and Cathy, when she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: learned the master had lost her whip in attending on the stranger,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: showed her humour by grinning and spitting at the stupid little thing;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: earning for her pains a sound blow from her father, to teach her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: cleaner manners. They entirely refused to have it in bed with them, or
title: Wuthering Heights

text: even in their room; and I had no more sense, so I put it on the landing
title: Wuthering Heights

text: of the stairs, hoping it might be gone on the morrow. By chance, or
title: Wuthering Heights

text: else attracted by hearing his voice, it crept to Mr. Earnshaw’s door,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and there he found it on quitting his chamber. Inquiries were made as
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to how it got there; I was obliged to confess, and in recompense for my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: cowardice and inhumanity was sent out of the house.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: This was Heathcliff’s first introduction to the family. On coming back
title: Wuthering Heights

text: a few days afterwards (for I did not consider my banishment perpetual),
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I found they had christened him “Heathcliff”: it was the name of a son
title: Wuthering Heights

text: who died in childhood, and it has served him ever since, both for
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Christian and surname. Miss Cathy and he were now very thick; but
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Hindley hated him: and to say the truth I did the same; and we plagued
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and went on with him shamefully: for I wasn’t reasonable enough to feel
title: Wuthering Heights

text: my injustice, and the mistress never put in a word on his behalf when
title: Wuthering Heights

text: she saw him wronged.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: He seemed a sullen, patient child; hardened, perhaps, to ill-treatment:
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he would stand Hindley’s blows without winking or shedding a tear, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: my pinches moved him only to draw in a breath and open his eyes, as if
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he had hurt himself by accident, and nobody was to blame. This
title: Wuthering Heights

text: endurance made old Earnshaw furious, when he discovered his son
title: Wuthering Heights

text: persecuting the poor fatherless child, as he called him. He took to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff strangely, believing all he said (for that matter, he said
title: Wuthering Heights

text: precious little, and generally the truth), and petting him up far above
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Cathy, who was too mischievous and wayward for a favourite.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: So, from the very beginning, he bred bad feeling in the house; and at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Mrs. Earnshaw’s death, which happened in less than two years after, the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: young master had learned to regard his father as an oppressor rather
title: Wuthering Heights

text: than a friend, and Heathcliff as a usurper of his parent’s affections
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and his privileges; and he grew bitter with brooding over these
title: Wuthering Heights

text: injuries. I sympathised a while; but when the children fell ill of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: measles, and I had to tend them, and take on me the cares of a woman at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: once, I changed my idea. Heathcliff was dangerously sick; and while he
title: Wuthering Heights

text: lay at the worst he would have me constantly by his pillow: I suppose
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he felt I did a good deal for him, and he hadn’t wit to guess that I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was compelled to do it. However, I will say this, he was the quietest
title: Wuthering Heights

text: child that ever nurse watched over. The difference between him and the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: others forced me to be less partial. Cathy and her brother harassed me
title: Wuthering Heights

text: terribly: _he_ was as uncomplaining as a lamb; though hardness, not
title: Wuthering Heights

text: gentleness, made him give little trouble.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: He got through, and the doctor affirmed it was in a great measure owing
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to me, and praised me for my care. I was vain of his commendations, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: softened towards the being by whose means I earned them, and thus
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Hindley lost his last ally: still I couldn’t dote on Heathcliff, and I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: wondered often what my master saw to admire so much in the sullen boy;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: who never, to my recollection, repaid his indulgence by any sign of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: gratitude. He was not insolent to his benefactor, he was simply
title: Wuthering Heights

text: insensible; though knowing perfectly the hold he had on his heart, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: conscious he had only to speak and all the house would be obliged to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bend to his wishes. As an instance, I remember Mr. Earnshaw once bought
title: Wuthering Heights

text: a couple of colts at the parish fair, and gave the lads each one.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff took the handsomest, but it soon fell lame, and when he
title: Wuthering Heights

text: discovered it, he said to Hindley—
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “You must exchange horses with me: I don’t like mine; and if you won’t
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I shall tell your father of the three thrashings you’ve given me this
title: Wuthering Heights

text: week, and show him my arm, which is black to the shoulder.” Hindley put
title: Wuthering Heights

text: out his tongue, and cuffed him over the ears. “You’d better do it at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: once,” he persisted, escaping to the porch (they were in the stable):
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “you will have to: and if I speak of these blows, you’ll get them again
title: Wuthering Heights

text: with interest.” “Off, dog!” cried Hindley, threatening him with an iron
title: Wuthering Heights

text: weight used for weighing potatoes and hay. “Throw it,” he replied,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: standing still, “and then I’ll tell how you boasted that you would turn
title: Wuthering Heights

text: me out of doors as soon as he died, and see whether he will not turn
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you out directly.” Hindley threw it, hitting him on the breast, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: down he fell, but staggered up immediately, breathless and white; and,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: had not I prevented it, he would have gone just so to the master, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: got full revenge by letting his condition plead for him, intimating who
title: Wuthering Heights

text: had caused it. “Take my colt, Gipsy, then!” said young Earnshaw. “And I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: pray that he may break your neck: take him, and be damned, you beggarly
title: Wuthering Heights

text: interloper! and wheedle my father out of all he has: only afterwards
title: Wuthering Heights

text: show him what you are, imp of Satan.—And take that, I hope he’ll kick
title: Wuthering Heights

text: out your brains!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff had gone to loose the beast, and shift it to his own stall;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he was passing behind it, when Hindley finished his speech by knocking
title: Wuthering Heights

text: him under its feet, and without stopping to examine whether his hopes
title: Wuthering Heights

text: were fulfilled, ran away as fast as he could. I was surprised to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: witness how coolly the child gathered himself up, and went on with his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: intention; exchanging saddles and all, and then sitting down on a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bundle of hay to overcome the qualm which the violent blow occasioned,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: before he entered the house. I persuaded him easily to let me lay the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: blame of his bruises on the horse: he minded little what tale was told
title: Wuthering Heights

text: since he had what he wanted. He complained so seldom, indeed, of such
title: Wuthering Heights

text: stirs as these, that I really thought him not vindictive: I was
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER V
title: Wuthering Heights

text: In the course of time Mr. Earnshaw began to fail. He had been active
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and healthy, yet his strength left him suddenly; and when he was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: confined to the chimney-corner he grew grievously irritable. A nothing
title: Wuthering Heights

text: vexed him; and suspected slights of his authority nearly threw him into
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fits. This was especially to be remarked if any one attempted to impose
title: Wuthering Heights

text: upon, or domineer over, his favourite: he was painfully jealous lest a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: word should be spoken amiss to him; seeming to have got into his head
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the notion that, because he liked Heathcliff, all hated, and longed to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: do him an ill-turn. It was a disadvantage to the lad; for the kinder
title: Wuthering Heights

text: among us did not wish to fret the master, so we humoured his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: partiality; and that humouring was rich nourishment to the child’s
title: Wuthering Heights

text: pride and black tempers. Still it became in a manner necessary; twice,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: or thrice, Hindley’s manifestation of scorn, while his father was near,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: roused the old man to a fury: he seized his stick to strike him, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: shook with rage that he could not do it.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: At last, our curate (we had a curate then who made the living answer by
title: Wuthering Heights

text: teaching the little Lintons and Earnshaws, and farming his bit of land
title: Wuthering Heights

text: himself) advised that the young man should be sent to college; and Mr.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Earnshaw agreed, though with a heavy spirit, for he said—“Hindley was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: nought, and would never thrive as where he wandered.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I hoped heartily we should have peace now. It hurt me to think the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: master should be made uncomfortable by his own good deed. I fancied the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: discontent of age and disease arose from his family disagreements; as
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he would have it that it did: really, you know, sir, it was in his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sinking frame. We might have got on tolerably, notwithstanding, but for
title: Wuthering Heights

text: two people—Miss Cathy, and Joseph, the servant: you saw him, I daresay,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: up yonder. He was, and is yet most likely, the wearisomest
title: Wuthering Heights

text: self-righteous Pharisee that ever ransacked a Bible to rake the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: promises to himself and fling the curses to his neighbours. By his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: knack of sermonising and pious discoursing, he contrived to make a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: great impression on Mr. Earnshaw; and the more feeble the master
title: Wuthering Heights

text: became, the more influence he gained. He was relentless in worrying him
title: Wuthering Heights

text: about his soul’s concerns, and about ruling his children rigidly. He
title: Wuthering Heights

text: encouraged him to regard Hindley as a reprobate; and, night after
title: Wuthering Heights

text: night, he regularly grumbled out a long string of tales against
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff and Catherine: always minding to flatter Earnshaw’s weakness
title: Wuthering Heights

text: by heaping the heaviest blame on the latter.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Certainly she had ways with her such as I never saw a child take up
title: Wuthering Heights

text: before; and she put all of us past our patience fifty times and oftener
title: Wuthering Heights

text: in a day: from the hour she came downstairs till the hour she went to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bed, we had not a minute’s security that she wouldn’t be in mischief.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Her spirits were always at high-water mark, her tongue always
title: Wuthering Heights

text: going—singing, laughing, and plaguing everybody who would not do the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: same. A wild, wicked slip she was—but she had the bonniest eye, the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sweetest smile, and lightest foot in the parish: and, after all, I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: believe she meant no harm; for when once she made you cry in good
title: Wuthering Heights

text: earnest, it seldom happened that she would not keep you company, and

title: Wuthering Heights

text: But the hour came, at last, that ended Mr. Earnshaw’s troubles on
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: fire-side. A high wind blustered round the house, and roared in the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: chimney: it sounded wild and stormy, yet it was not cold, and we were
title: Wuthering Heights

text: all together—I, a little removed from the hearth, busy at my knitting,
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: on: no parson in the world ever pictured heaven so beautifully as they
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Mr. Hindley came home to the funeral; and—a thing that amazed us, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: set the neighbours gossiping right and left—he brought a wife with him.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: What she was, and where she was born, he never informed us: probably,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: she had neither money nor name to recommend her, or he would scarcely
title: Wuthering Heights

text: have kept the union from his father.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: She was not one that would have disturbed the house much on her own
title: Wuthering Heights

text: account. Every object she saw, the moment she crossed the threshold,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: appeared to delight her; and every circumstance that took place about
title: Wuthering Heights

text: her: except the preparing for the burial, and the presence of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mourners. I thought she was half silly, from her behaviour while that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: went on: she ran into her chamber, and made me come with her, though I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: should have been dressing the children: and there she sat shivering and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: clasping her hands, and asking repeatedly—“Are they gone yet?” Then she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: began describing with hysterical emotion the effect it produced on her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to see black; and started, and trembled, and, at last, fell
title: Wuthering Heights

text: a-weeping—and when I asked what was the matter, answered, she didn’t
title: Wuthering Heights

text: know; but she felt so afraid of dying! I imagined her as little likely
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to die as myself. She was rather thin, but young, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fresh-complexioned, and her eyes sparkled as bright as diamonds. I did
title: Wuthering Heights

text: remark, to be sure, that mounting the stairs made her breathe very
title: Wuthering Heights

text: quick; that the least sudden noise set her all in a quiver, and that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: she coughed troublesomely sometimes: but I knew nothing of what these
title: Wuthering Heights

text: symptoms portended, and had no impulse to sympathise with her. We don’t
title: Wuthering Heights

text: in general take to foreigners here, Mr. Lockwood, unless they take to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: us first.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Young Earnshaw was altered considerably in the three years of his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: absence. He had grown sparer, and lost his colour, and spoke and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: dressed quite differently; and, on the very day of his return, he told
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Joseph and me we must thenceforth quarter ourselves in the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: back-kitchen, and leave the house for him. Indeed, he would have
title: Wuthering Heights

text: carpeted and papered a small spare room for a parlour; but his wife
title: Wuthering Heights

text: expressed such pleasure at the white floor and huge glowing fireplace,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: at the pewter dishes and delf-case, and dog-kennel, and the wide space
title: Wuthering Heights

text: there was to move about in where they usually sat, that he thought it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: unnecessary to her comfort, and so dropped the intention.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: She expressed pleasure, too, at finding a sister among her new
title: Wuthering Heights

text: acquaintance; and she prattled to Catherine, and kissed her, and ran
title: Wuthering Heights

text: about with her, and gave her quantities of presents, at the beginning.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Her affection tired very soon, however, and when she grew peevish,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Hindley became tyrannical. A few words from her, evincing a dislike to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff, were enough to rouse in him all his old hatred of the boy.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: He drove him from their company to the servants, deprived him of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: instructions of the curate, and insisted that he should labour out of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: doors instead; compelling him to do so as hard as any other lad on the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: farm.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff bore his degradation pretty well at first, because Cathy
title: Wuthering Heights

text: taught him what she learnt, and worked or played with him in the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fields. They both promised fair to grow up as rude as savages; the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: young master being entirely negligent how they behaved, and what they
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: going to church on Sundays, only Joseph and the curate reprimanded his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: carelessness when they absented themselves; and that reminded him to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: order Heathcliff a flogging, and Catherine a fast from dinner or
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: grew a mere thing to laugh at. The curate might set as many chapters as
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: for fear of losing the small power I still retained over the unfriended
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: the sitting-room, for making a noise, or a light offence of the kind;
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Cathy stayed at Thrushcross Grange five weeks: till Christmas. By that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: time her ankle was thoroughly cured, and her manners much improved. The
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mistress visited her often in the interval, and commenced her plan of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: reform by trying to raise her self-respect with fine clothes and

text: CHAPTER VIII
title: Wuthering Heights

text: On the morning of a fine June day my first bonny little nursling, and
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: For two months the fugitives remained absent; in those two months, Mrs.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Linton encountered and conquered the worst shock of what was
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “How did she die?” he resumed, at last—fain, notwithstanding his

text: “Quietly as a lamb!” I answered, aloud. “She drew a sigh, and stretched
title: Wuthering Heights

text: herself, like a child reviving, and sinking again to sleep; and five
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Her senses never returned: she recognised nobody from the time you
title: Wuthering Heights

text: left her,” I said. “She lies with a sweet smile on her face; and her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: latest ideas wandered back to pleasant early days. Her life closed in a

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Why, she’s a liar to the end! Where is she? Not _there_—not in
title: Wuthering Heights

text: heaven—not perished—where? Oh! you said you cared nothing for my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sufferings! And I pray one prayer—I repeat it till my tongue
title: Wuthering Heights

text: stiffens—Catherine Earnshaw, may you not rest as long as I am living;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you said I killed you—haunt me, then! The murdered _do_ haunt their
title: Wuthering Heights

text: murderers, I believe. I know that ghosts _have_ wandered on earth. Be
title: Wuthering Heights

text: with me always—take any form—drive me mad! only _do_ not leave me in
title: Wuthering Heights

text: this abyss, where I cannot find you! Oh, God! it is unutterable! I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: _cannot_ live without my life! I _cannot_ live without my soul!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: He dashed his head against the knotted trunk; and, lifting up his eyes,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: howled, not like a man, but like a savage beast being goaded to death
title: Wuthering Heights

text: with knives and spears. I observed several splashes of blood about the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bark of the tree, and his hand and forehead were both stained; probably
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the scene I witnessed was a repetition of others acted during the
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: reluctant to quit him so. But the moment he recollected himself enough
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to notice me watching, he thundered a command for me to go, and I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: obeyed. He was beyond my skill to quiet or console!
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Mrs. Linton’s funeral was appointed to take place on the Friday
title: Wuthering Heights

text: following her decease; and till then her coffin remained uncovered, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: strewn with flowers and scented leaves, in the great drawing-room.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Linton spent his days and nights there, a sleepless guardian; and—a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: circumstance concealed from all but me—Heathcliff spent his nights, at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: least, outside, equally a stranger to repose. I held no communication
title: Wuthering Heights

text: with him; still, I was conscious of his design to enter, if he could;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and on the Tuesday, a little after dark, when my master, from sheer
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fatigue, had been compelled to retire a couple of hours, I went and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: opened one of the windows; moved by his perseverance to give him a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: chance of bestowing on the faded image of his idol one final adieu. He
title: Wuthering Heights

text: did not omit to avail himself of the opportunity, cautiously and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: briefly; too cautiously to betray his presence by the slightest noise.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Indeed, I shouldn’t have discovered that he had been there, except for
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the disarrangement of the drapery about the corpse’s face, and for
title: Wuthering Heights

text: observing on the floor a curl of light hair, fastened with a silver
title: Wuthering Heights

text: thread; which, on examination, I ascertained to have been taken from a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: locket hung round Catherine’s neck. Heathcliff had opened the trinket
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and cast out its contents, replacing them by a black lock of his own. I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: twisted the two, and enclosed them together.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Mr. Earnshaw was, of course, invited to attend the remains of his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sister to the grave; he sent no excuse, but he never came; so that,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: besides her husband, the mourners were wholly composed of tenants and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: servants. Isabella was not asked.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: The place of Catherine’s interment, to the surprise of the villagers,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was neither in the chapel under the carved monument of the Lintons, nor
title: Wuthering Heights

text: yet by the tombs of her own relations, outside. It was dug on a green
title: Wuthering Heights

text: slope in a corner of the kirkyard, where the wall is so low that heath
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and bilberry-plants have climbed over it from the moor; and peat-mould
title: Wuthering Heights

text: almost buries it. Her husband lies in the same spot now; and they have
title: Wuthering Heights

text: each a simple headstone above, and a plain grey block at their feet, to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mark the graves.

text: CHAPTER XVII
title: Wuthering Heights

text: That Friday made the last of our fine days for a month. In the evening
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the weather broke: the wind shifted from south to north-east, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: brought rain first, and then sleet and snow. On the morrow one could
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hardly imagine that there had been three weeks of summer: the primroses
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and crocuses were hidden under wintry drifts; the larks were silent,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the young leaves of the early trees smitten and blackened. And dreary,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and chill, and dismal, that morrow did creep over! My master kept his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: room; I took possession of the lonely parlour, converting it into a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: nursery: and there I was, sitting with the moaning doll of a child laid
title: Wuthering Heights

text: on my knee; rocking it to and fro, and watching, meanwhile, the still
title: Wuthering Heights

text: driving flakes build up the uncurtained window, when the door opened,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and some person entered, out of breath and laughing! My anger was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: greater than my astonishment for a minute. I supposed it one of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: maids, and I cried—“Have done! How dare you show your giddiness here?
title: Wuthering Heights

text: What would Mr. Linton say if he heard you?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Excuse me!” answered a familiar voice; “but I know Edgar is in bed,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and I cannot stop myself.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: With that the speaker came forward to the fire, panting and holding her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hand to her side.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I have run the whole way from Wuthering Heights!” she continued, after
title: Wuthering Heights

text: a pause; “except where I’ve flown. I couldn’t count the number of falls
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I’ve had. Oh, I’m aching all over! Don’t be alarmed! There shall be an
title: Wuthering Heights

text: explanation as soon as I can give it; only just have the goodness to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: step out and order the carriage to take me on to Gimmerton, and tell a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: servant to seek up a few clothes in my wardrobe.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: The intruder was Mrs. Heathcliff. She certainly seemed in no laughing
title: Wuthering Heights

text: predicament: her hair streamed on her shoulders, dripping with snow and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: water; she was dressed in the girlish dress she commonly wore,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: befitting her age more than her position: a low frock with short
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sleeves, and nothing on either head or neck. The frock was of light
title: Wuthering Heights

text: silk, and clung to her with wet, and her feet were protected merely by
title: Wuthering Heights

text: thin slippers; add to this a deep cut under one ear, which only the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: cold prevented from bleeding profusely, a white face scratched and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bruised, and a frame hardly able to support itself through fatigue; and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you may fancy my first fright was not much allayed when I had had
title: Wuthering Heights

text: leisure to examine her.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “My dear young lady,” I exclaimed, “I’ll stir nowhere, and hear
title: Wuthering Heights

text: nothing, till you have removed every article of your clothes, and put
title: Wuthering Heights

text: on dry things; and certainly you shall not go to Gimmerton to-night, so
title: Wuthering Heights

text: it is needless to order the carriage.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Certainly I shall,” she said; “walking or riding: yet I’ve no
title: Wuthering Heights

text: objection to dress myself decently. And—ah, see how it flows down my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: neck now! The fire does make it smart.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: She insisted on my fulfilling her directions, before she would let me
title: Wuthering Heights

text: touch her; and not till after the coachman had been instructed to get
title: Wuthering Heights

text: ready, and a maid set to pack up some necessary attire, did I obtain
title: Wuthering Heights

text: her consent for binding the wound and helping to change her garments.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Now, Ellen,” she said, when my task was finished and she was seated in
title: Wuthering Heights

text: an easy-chair on the hearth, with a cup of tea before her, “you sit
title: Wuthering Heights

text: down opposite me, and put poor Catherine’s baby away: I don’t like to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: see it! You mustn’t think I care little for Catherine, because I
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: than any one else has reason to cry. We parted unreconciled, you
title: Wuthering Heights

text: remember, and I sha’n’t forgive myself. But, for all that, I was not
title: Wuthering Heights

text: going to sympathise with him—the brute beast! Oh, give me the poker!
title: Wuthering Heights

text: This is the last thing of his I have about me:” she slipped the gold
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: she continued, striking it with childish spite, “and then I’ll burn
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “There! he shall buy another, if he gets me back again. He’d be capable
title: Wuthering Heights

text: of coming to seek me, to tease Edgar. I dare not stay, lest that notion
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Hush, hush! He’s a human being,” I said. “Be more charitable: there

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Yesterday, you know, Mr. Earnshaw should have been at the funeral. He
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Heathcliff—I shudder to name him! has been a stranger in the house
title: Wuthering Heights

text: from last Sunday till to-day. Whether the angels have fed him, or his
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: The twelve years, continued Mrs. Dean, following that dismal period
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER XIX
title: Wuthering Heights

text: A letter, edged with black, announced the day of my master’s return.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Isabella was dead; and he wrote to bid me get mourning for his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: daughter, and arrange a room, and other accommodations, for his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: youthful nephew. Catherine ran wild with joy at the idea of welcoming
title: Wuthering Heights

text: her father back; and indulged most sanguine anticipations of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: innumerable excellencies of her “real” cousin. The evening of their
title: Wuthering Heights

text: expected arrival came. Since early morning she had been busy ordering
title: Wuthering Heights

text: her own small affairs; and now attired in her new black frock—poor
title: Wuthering Heights

text: thing! her aunt’s death impressed her with no definite sorrow—she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: obliged me, by constant worrying, to walk with her down through the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: grounds to meet them.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Linton is just six months younger than I am,” she chattered, as we
title: Wuthering Heights

text: strolled leisurely over the swells and hollows of mossy turf, under
title: Wuthering Heights

text: shadow of the trees. “How delightful it will be to have him for a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: playfellow! Aunt Isabella sent papa a beautiful lock of his hair; it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was lighter than mine—more flaxen, and quite as fine. I have it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: carefully preserved in a little glass box; and I’ve often thought what
title: Wuthering Heights

text: a pleasure it would be to see its owner. Oh! I am happy—and papa, dear,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: dear papa! Come, Ellen, let us run! come, run.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: She ran, and returned and ran again, many times before my sober
title: Wuthering Heights

text: footsteps reached the gate, and then she seated herself on the grassy
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bank beside the path, and tried to wait patiently; but that was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: impossible: she couldn’t be still a minute.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “How long they are!” she exclaimed. “Ah, I see some dust on the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: road—they are coming! No! When will they be here? May we not go a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: little way—half a mile, Ellen, only just half a mile? Do say yes, to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: that clump of birches at the turn!”

text: I refused staunchly. At length her suspense was ended: the travelling
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: arms as soon as she caught her father’s face looking from the window.
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: told her to come, and they walked together up the park, while I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hastened before to prepare the servants.
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER XX
title: Wuthering Heights

text: To obviate the danger of this threat being fulfilled, Mr. Linton
title: Wuthering Heights

text: commissioned me to take the boy home early, on Catherine’s pony; and,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: said he—“As we shall now have no influence over his destiny, good or
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bad, you must say nothing of where he is gone to my daughter: she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: cannot associate with him hereafter, and it is better for her to remain
title: Wuthering Heights

text: in ignorance of his proximity; lest she should be restless, and anxious
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to visit the Heights. Merely tell her his father sent for him suddenly,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and he has been obliged to leave us.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Linton was very reluctant to be roused from his bed at five o’clock,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and astonished to be informed that he must prepare for further
title: Wuthering Heights

text: travelling; but I softened off the matter by stating that he was going
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to spend some time with his father, Mr. Heathcliff, who wished to see
title: Wuthering Heights

text: him so much, he did not like to defer the pleasure till he should
title: Wuthering Heights

text: recover from his late journey.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “My father!” he cried, in strange perplexity. “Mamma never told me I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: had a father. Where does he live? I’d rather stay with uncle.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “He lives a little distance from the Grange,” I replied; “just beyond
title: Wuthering Heights

text: those hills: not so far, but you may walk over here when you get
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hearty. And you should be glad to go home, and to see him. You must try
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to love him, as you did your mother, and then he will love you.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “But why have I not heard of him before?” asked Linton. “Why didn’t
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mamma and he live together, as other people do?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “He had business to keep him in the north,” I answered, “and your
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mother’s health required her to reside in the south.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “And why didn’t mamma speak to me about him?” persevered the child.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “She often talked of uncle, and I learnt to love him long ago. How am I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to love papa? I don’t know him.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Oh, all children love their parents,” I said. “Your mother, perhaps,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: thought you would want to be with him if she mentioned him often to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you. Let us make haste. An early ride on such a beautiful morning is
title: Wuthering Heights

text: much preferable to an hour’s more sleep.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Is _she_ to go with us,” he demanded, “the little girl I saw
title: Wuthering Heights

text: yesterday?”

text: “Not now,” replied I.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Is uncle?” he continued.

text: Linton sank back on his pillow and fell into a brown study.

title: Wuthering Heights

text: mean to take me.”

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Is Wuthering Heights as pleasant a place as Thrushcross Grange?” he
title: Wuthering Heights

text: inquired, turning to take a last glance into the valley, whence a light
title: Wuthering Heights

text: mist mounted and formed a fleecy cloud on the skirts of the blue.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “It is not so buried in trees,” I replied, “and it is not quite so
title: Wuthering Heights

text: large, but you can see the country beautifully all round; and the air
title: Wuthering Heights

text: is healthier for you—fresher and drier. You will, perhaps, think the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: building old and dark at first; though it is a respectable house: the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: next best in the neighbourhood. And you will have such nice rambles on
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the moors. Hareton Earnshaw—that is, Miss Cathy’s other cousin, and so
title: Wuthering Heights

text: yours in a manner—will show you all the sweetest spots; and you can
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: now and then, your uncle may join you in a walk: he does, frequently,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: walk out on the hills.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “And what is my father like?” he asked. “Is he as young and handsome as
title: Wuthering Heights

text: uncle?”

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: so gentle and kind at first, perhaps, because it is not his way: still,
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: of you than any uncle, for you are his own.”

text: “Black hair and eyes!” mused Linton. “I can’t fancy him. Then I am not

text: CHAPTER XXI
title: Wuthering Heights

text: We had sad work with little Cathy that day: she rose in high glee,
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER XXII
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Summer drew to an end, and early autumn: it was past Michaelmas, but
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the harvest was late that year, and a few of our fields were still
title: Wuthering Heights

text: uncleared. Mr. Linton and his daughter would frequently walk out among
title: Wuthering Heights

text: the reapers; at the carrying of the last sheaves they stayed till dusk,
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: throughout the whole of the winter, nearly without intermission.
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: sadder and duller since its abandonment; and her father insisted on her
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: three hours, from my numerous diurnal occupations, to follow her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: footsteps, and then my society was obviously less desirable than his.
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER XXIX
title: Wuthering Heights

text: The evening after the funeral, my young lady and I were seated in the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: library; now musing mournfully—one of us despairingly—on our loss, now
title: Wuthering Heights

text: venturing conjectures as to the gloomy future.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: We had just agreed the best destiny which could await Catherine would
title: Wuthering Heights

text: be a permission to continue resident at the Grange; at least during
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Linton’s life: he being allowed to join her there, and I to remain as
title: Wuthering Heights

text: housekeeper. That seemed rather too favourable an arrangement to be
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hoped for; and yet I did hope, and began to cheer up under the prospect
title: Wuthering Heights

text: of retaining my home and my employment, and, above all, my beloved
title: Wuthering Heights

text: young mistress; when a servant—one of the discarded ones, not yet
title: Wuthering Heights

text: departed—rushed hastily in, and said “that devil Heathcliff” was coming
title: Wuthering Heights

text: through the court: should he fasten the door in his face?
title: Wuthering Heights

text: If we had been mad enough to order that proceeding, we had not time. He
title: Wuthering Heights

text: made no ceremony of knocking or announcing his name: he was master, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: availed himself of the master’s privilege to walk straight in, without
title: Wuthering Heights

text: saying a word. The sound of our informant’s voice directed him to the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: library; he entered and motioning him out, shut the door.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: It was the same room into which he had been ushered, as a guest,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: eighteen years before: the same moon shone through the window; and the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: same autumn landscape lay outside. We had not yet lighted a candle, but
title: Wuthering Heights

text: all the apartment was visible, even to the portraits on the wall: the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: splendid head of Mrs. Linton, and the graceful one of her husband.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heathcliff advanced to the hearth. Time had little altered his person
title: Wuthering Heights

text: either. There was the same man: his dark face rather sallower and more
title: Wuthering Heights

text: composed, his frame a stone or two heavier, perhaps, and no other
title: Wuthering Heights

text: difference. Catherine had risen with an impulse to dash out, when she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: saw him.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Stop!” he said, arresting her by the arm. “No more runnings away!
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Where would you go? I’m come to fetch you home; and I hope you’ll be a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: dutiful daughter and not encourage my son to further disobedience. I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: was embarrassed how to punish him when I discovered his part in the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: business: he’s such a cobweb, a pinch would annihilate him; but you’ll
title: Wuthering Heights

text: see by his look that he has received his due! I brought him down one
title: Wuthering Heights

text: evening, the day before yesterday, and just set him in a chair, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: never touched him afterwards. I sent Hareton out, and we had the room
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to ourselves. In two hours, I called Joseph to carry him up again; and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: since then my presence is as potent on his nerves as a ghost; and I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: fancy he sees me often, though I am not near. Hareton says he wakes and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: shrieks in the night by the hour together, and calls you to protect him
title: Wuthering Heights

text: from me; and, whether you like your precious mate, or not, you must
title: Wuthering Heights

text: come: he’s your concern now; I yield all my interest in him to you.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Why not let Catherine continue here,” I pleaded, “and send Master
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Linton to her? As you hate them both, you’d not miss them: they _can_
title: Wuthering Heights

text: only be a daily plague to your unnatural heart.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I’m seeking a tenant for the Grange,” he answered; “and I want my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: children about me, to be sure. Besides, that lass owes me her services
title: Wuthering Heights

text: for her bread. I’m not going to nurture her in luxury and idleness
title: Wuthering Heights

text: after Linton is gone. Make haste and get ready, now; and don’t oblige
title: Wuthering Heights

text: me to compel you.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I shall,” said Catherine. “Linton is all I have to love in the world,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and though you have done what you could to make him hateful to me, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: me to him, you _cannot_ make us hate each other. And I defy you to hurt
title: Wuthering Heights

text: him when I am by, and I defy you to frighten me!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “You are a boastful champion,” replied Heathcliff; “but I don’t like
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you well enough to hurt him: you shall get the full benefit of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: torment, as long as it lasts. It is not I who will make him hateful to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you—it is his own sweet spirit. He’s as bitter as gall at your
title: Wuthering Heights

text: desertion and its consequences: don’t expect thanks for this noble
title: Wuthering Heights

text: devotion. I heard him draw a pleasant picture to Zillah of what he
title: Wuthering Heights

text: would do if he were as strong as I: the inclination is there, and his
title: Wuthering Heights

text: very weakness will sharpen his wits to find a substitute for strength.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I know he has a bad nature,” said Catherine: “he’s your son. But I’m
title: Wuthering Heights

text: glad I’ve a better, to forgive it; and I know he loves me, and for that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: reason I love him. Mr. Heathcliff, _you_ have _nobody_ to love you;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and, however miserable you make us, we shall still have the revenge of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: thinking that your cruelty arises from your greater misery. You _are_
title: Wuthering Heights

text: miserable, are you not? Lonely, like the devil, and envious like him?
title: Wuthering Heights

text: _Nobody_ loves you—_nobody_ will cry for you when you die! I wouldn’t
title: Wuthering Heights

text: be you!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Catherine spoke with a kind of dreary triumph: she seemed to have made
title: Wuthering Heights

text: up her mind to enter into the spirit of her future family, and draw
title: Wuthering Heights

text: pleasure from the griefs of her enemies.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “You shall be sorry to be yourself presently,” said her father-in-law,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “if you stand there another minute. Begone, witch, and get your
title: Wuthering Heights

text: things!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: She scornfully withdrew. In her absence I began to beg for Zillah’s
title: Wuthering Heights

text: place at the Heights, offering to resign mine to her; but he would
title: Wuthering Heights

text: suffer it on no account. He bid me be silent; and then, for the first
title: Wuthering Heights

text: time, allowed himself a glance round the room and a look at the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: pictures. Having studied Mrs. Linton’s, he said—“I shall have that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: home. Not because I need it, but—” He turned abruptly to the fire, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: continued, with what, for lack of a better word, I must call a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: smile—“I’ll tell you what I did yesterday! I got the sexton, who was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: digging Linton’s grave, to remove the earth off her coffin lid, and I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: opened it. I thought, once, I would have stayed there: when I saw her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: face again—it is hers yet!—he had hard work to stir me; but he said it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: would change if the air blew on it, and so I struck one side of the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: coffin loose, and covered it up: not Linton’s side, damn him! I wish
title: Wuthering Heights

text: he’d been soldered in lead. And I bribed the sexton to pull it away
title: Wuthering Heights

text: when I’m laid there, and slide mine out too; I’ll have it made so: and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: then by the time Linton gets to us he’ll not know which is which!”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “You were very wicked, Mr. Heathcliff!” I exclaimed; “were you not
title: Wuthering Heights

text: ashamed to disturb the dead?”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “I disturbed nobody, Nelly,” he replied; “and I gave some ease to
title: Wuthering Heights

text: myself. I shall be a great deal more comfortable now; and you’ll have a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: better chance of keeping me underground, when I get there. Disturbed
title: Wuthering Heights

text: her? No! she has disturbed me, night and day, through eighteen
title: Wuthering Heights

text: years—incessantly—remorselessly—till yesternight; and yesternight I was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: tranquil. I dreamt I was sleeping the last sleep by that sleeper, with
title: Wuthering Heights

text: my heart stopped and my cheek frozen against hers.”
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “And if she had been dissolved into earth, or worse, what would you
title: Wuthering Heights

text: have dreamt of then?” I said.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “Of dissolving with her, and being more happy still!” he answered. “Do
title: Wuthering Heights

text: you suppose I dread any change of that sort? I expected such a
title: Wuthering Heights

text: transformation on raising the lid, but I’m better pleased that it should
title: Wuthering Heights

text: not commence till I share it. Besides, unless I had received a distinct
title: Wuthering Heights

text: impression of her passionless features, that strange feeling would
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hardly have been removed. It began oddly. You know I was wild after she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: died; and eternally, from dawn to dawn, praying her to return to me her
title: Wuthering Heights

text: spirit! I have a strong faith in ghosts: I have a conviction that they
title: Wuthering Heights

text: can, and do, exist among us! The day she was buried, there came a fall
title: Wuthering Heights

text: of snow. In the evening I went to the churchyard. It blew bleak as
title: Wuthering Heights

text: winter—all round was solitary. I didn’t fear that her fool of a husband
title: Wuthering Heights

text: would wander up the glen so late; and no one else had business to bring
title: Wuthering Heights

text: them there. Being alone, and conscious two yards of loose earth was the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sole barrier between us, I said to myself—‘I’ll have her in my arms
title: Wuthering Heights

text: again! If she be cold, I’ll think it is this north wind that chills
title: Wuthering Heights

text: _me_; and if she be motionless, it is sleep.’ I got a spade from the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: tool-house, and began to delve with all my might—it scraped the coffin;
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I fell to work with my hands; the wood commenced cracking about the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: screws; I was on the point of attaining my object, when it seemed that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I heard a sigh from some one above, close at the edge of the grave, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: bending down. ‘If I can only get this off,’ I muttered, ‘I wish they
title: Wuthering Heights

text: may shovel in the earth over us both!’ and I wrenched at it more
title: Wuthering Heights

text: desperately still. There was another sigh, close at my ear. I appeared
title: Wuthering Heights

text: to feel the warm breath of it displacing the sleet-laden wind. I knew
title: Wuthering Heights

text: no living thing in flesh and blood was by; but, as certainly as you
title: Wuthering Heights

text: perceive the approach to some substantial body in the dark, though it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: cannot be discerned, so certainly I felt that Cathy was there: not
title: Wuthering Heights

text: under me, but on the earth. A sudden sense of relief flowed from my
title: Wuthering Heights

text: heart through every limb. I relinquished my labour of agony, and turned
title: Wuthering Heights

text: consoled at once: unspeakably consoled. Her presence was with me: it
title: Wuthering Heights

text: remained while I re-filled the grave, and led me home. You may laugh,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: if you will; but I was sure I should see her there. I was sure she was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: with me, and I could not help talking to her. Having reached the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heights, I rushed eagerly to the door. It was fastened; and, I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: remember, that accursed Earnshaw and my wife opposed my entrance. I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: remember stopping to kick the breath out of him, and then hurrying
title: Wuthering Heights

text: upstairs, to my room and hers. I looked round impatiently—I felt her by
title: Wuthering Heights

text: me—I could _almost_ see her, and yet I _could not_! I ought to have
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sweat blood then, from the anguish of my yearning—from the fervour of
title: Wuthering Heights

text: my supplications to have but one glimpse! I had not one. She showed
title: Wuthering Heights

text: herself, as she often was in life, a devil to me! And, since then,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sometimes more and sometimes less, I’ve been the sport of that
title: Wuthering Heights

text: intolerable torture! Infernal! keeping my nerves at such a stretch
title: Wuthering Heights

text: that, if they had not resembled catgut, they would long ago have
title: Wuthering Heights

text: relaxed to the feebleness of Linton’s. When I sat in the house with
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Hareton, it seemed that on going out I should meet her; when I walked
title: Wuthering Heights

text: on the moors I should meet her coming in. When I went from home I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: hastened to return; she _must_ be somewhere at the Heights, I was
title: Wuthering Heights

text: certain! And when I slept in her chamber—I was beaten out of that. I
title: Wuthering Heights

text: couldn’t lie there; for the moment I closed my eyes, she was either
title: Wuthering Heights

text: outside the window, or sliding back the panels, or entering the room,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: or even resting her darling head on the same pillow as she did when a
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: her, I’m pacified—a little. It was a strange way of killing: not by
title: Wuthering Heights

text: inches, but by fractions of hairbreadths, to beguile me with the
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: CHAPTER XXX
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I have paid a visit to the Heights, but I have not seen her since she
title: Wuthering Heights

text: left: Joseph held the door in his hand when I called to ask after her,
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and wouldn’t let me pass. He said Mrs. Linton was “thrang,” and the
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: otherwise I should hardly know who was dead and who living. She thinks
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Catherine haughty, and does not like her, I can guess by her talk. My
title: Wuthering Heights

text: young lady asked some aid of her when she first came; but Mr.
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: being a narrow-minded, selfish woman. Catherine evinced a child’s
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: little before you came, one day when we foregathered on the moor; and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: this is what she told me.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: “The first thing Mrs. Linton did,” she said, “on her arrival at the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: Heights, was to run upstairs, without even wishing good-evening to me
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: entered the house, and asked all in a quiver if the doctor might be
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

text: 1802.—This September I was invited to devastate the moors of a friend
title: Wuthering Heights

text: in the north, and on my journey to his abode, I unexpectedly came

text: CHAPTER XXXIV
title: Wuthering Heights

text: For some days after that evening, Mr. Heathcliff shunned meeting us at
title: Wuthering Heights

text: meals; yet he would not consent formally to exclude Hareton and Cathy.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: He had an aversion to yielding so completely to his feelings, choosing
title: Wuthering Heights

text: rather to absent himself; and eating once in twenty-four hours seemed
title: Wuthering Heights

text: sufficient sustenance for him.
title: Wuthering Heights

text: One night, after the family were in bed, I heard him go downstairs, and
title: Wuthering Heights

text: out at the front door. I did not hear him re-enter, and in the morning
title: Wuthering Heights

text: I found he was still away. We were in April then: the weather was sweet
title: Wuthering Heights

text: and warm, the grass as green as showers and sun could make it, and the
title: Wuthering Heights

text: two dwarf apple-trees near the southern wall in full bloom. After
title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Wuthering Heights

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _The characteristics of Miss Austen’s humour are so subtle and delicate
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that they are, perhaps, at all times easier to apprehend than to
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: apprehended by different persons. To me this humour seems to possess a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: greater affinity, on the whole, to that of Addison than to any other of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the numerous species of this great British genus. The differences of
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice
