text: we need not go beyond her own comparison to the art of a miniature
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: painter. To make this latter observation quite exact we must not use the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: term miniature in its restricted sense, and must think rather of Memling
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at one end of the history of painting and Meissonier at the other, than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of Cosway or any of his kind. And I am not so certain that I should
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: myself use the word “narrow” in connection with her. If her world is a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: microcosm, the cosmic quality of it is at least as eminent as the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: littleness. She does not touch what she did not feel herself called to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: paint; I am not so sure that she could not have painted what she did not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feel herself called to touch. It is at least remarkable that in two very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: short periods of writing--one of about three years, and another of not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much more than five--she executed six capital works, and has not left a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: single failure. It is possible that the romantic paste in her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: composition was defective: we must always remember that hardly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anybody born in her decade--that of the eighteenth-century
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seventies--independently exhibited the full romantic quality. Even Scott
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: required hill and mountain and ballad, even Coleridge metaphysics and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: German to enable them to chip the classical shell. Miss Austen was an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: English girl, brought up in a country retirement, at the time when
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ladies went back into the house if there was a white frost which might
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pierce their kid shoes, when a sudden cold was the subject of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gravest fears, when their studies, their ways, their conduct were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: subject to all those fantastic limits and restrictions against which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mary Wollstonecraft protested with better general sense than particular
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: taste or judgment. Miss Austen, too, drew back when the white frost
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: touched her shoes; but I think she would have made a pretty good journey
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: even in a black one._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _For if her knowledge was not very extended, she knew two things which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only genius knows. The one was humanity, and the other was art. On the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: first head she could not make a mistake; her men, though limited, are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: true, and her women are, in the old sense, “absolute.” As to art, if she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: has never tried idealism, her realism is real to a degree which makes
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the false realism of our own day look merely dead-alive. Take almost any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Frenchman, except the late M. de Maupassant, and watch him laboriously
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: piling up strokes in the hope of giving a complete impression. You get
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: none; you are lucky if, discarding two-thirds of what he gives, you can
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shape a real impression out of the rest. But with Miss Austen the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: myriad, trivial, unforced strokes build up the picture like magic.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Nothing is false; nothing is superfluous. When (to take the present book
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only) Mr. Collins changed his mind from Jane to Elizabeth “while Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet was stirring the fire” (and we know_ how _Mrs. Bennet would have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stirred the fire), when Mr. Darcy “brought his coffee-cup back_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself,” _the touch in each case is like that of Swift--“taller by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: breadth of my nail”--which impressed the half-reluctant Thackeray with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: just and outspoken admiration. Indeed, fantastic as it may seem, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should put Miss Austen as near to Swift in some ways, as I have put her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to Addison in others._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _This Swiftian quality appears in the present novel as it appears
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nowhere else in the character of the immortal, the ineffable Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collins. Mr. Collins is really_ great; _far greater than anything Addison
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ever did, almost great enough for Fielding or for Swift himself. It has
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been said that no one ever was like him. But in the first place,_ he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _was like him; he is there--alive, imperishable, more real than hundreds
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of prime ministers and archbishops, of “metals, semi-metals, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: distinguished philosophers.” In the second place, it is rash, I think,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to conclude that an actual Mr. Collins was impossible or non-existent at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the end of the eighteenth century. It is very interesting that we
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: possess, in this same gallery, what may be called a spoiled first
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: draught, or an unsuccessful study of him, in John Dashwood. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: formality, the under-breeding, the meanness, are there; but the portrait
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: is only half alive, and is felt to be even a little unnatural. Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collins is perfectly natural, and perfectly alive. In fact, for all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “miniature,” there is something gigantic in the way in which a certain
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: side, and more than one, of humanity, and especially eighteenth-century
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: humanity, its Philistinism, its well-meaning but hide-bound morality,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its formal pettiness, its grovelling respect for rank, its materialism,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its selfishness, receives exhibition. I will not admit that one speech
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or one action of this inestimable man is incapable of being reconciled
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with reality, and I should not wonder if many of these words and actions
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: are historically true._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _But the greatness of Mr. Collins could not have been so satisfactorily
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exhibited if his creatress had not adjusted so artfully to him the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: figures of Mr. Bennet and of Lady Catherine de Bourgh. The latter, like
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Collins himself, has been charged with exaggeration. There is,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: perhaps, a very faint shade of colour for the charge; but it seems to me
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very faint indeed. Even now I do not think that it would be impossible
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to find persons, especially female persons, not necessarily of noble
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: birth, as overbearing, as self-centred, as neglectful of good manners,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as Lady Catherine. A hundred years ago, an earl’s daughter, the Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Powerful (if not exactly Bountiful) of an out-of-the-way country parish,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rich, long out of marital authority, and so forth, had opportunities of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: developing these agreeable characteristics which seldom present
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: themselves now. As for Mr. Bennet, Miss Austen, and Mr. Darcy, and even
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Elizabeth herself, were, I am inclined to think, rather hard on him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for the “impropriety” of his conduct. His wife was evidently, and must
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always have been, a quite irreclaimable fool; and unless he had shot her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or himself there was no way out of it for a man of sense and spirit but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the ironic. From no other point of view is he open to any reproach,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: except for an excusable and not unnatural helplessness at the crisis of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the elopement, and his utterances are the most acutely delightful in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: consciously humorous kind--in the kind that we laugh with, not at--that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: even Miss Austen has put into the mouth of any of her characters. It is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: difficult to know whether he is most agreeable when talking to his wife,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or when putting Mr. Collins through his paces; but the general sense of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the world has probably been right in preferring to the first rank his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: consolation to the former when she maunders over the entail, “My dear,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: do not give way to such gloomy thoughts. Let us hope for better things.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Let us flatter ourselves that_ I _may be the survivor;” and his inquiry
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to his colossal cousin as to the compliments which Mr. Collins has just
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: related as made by himself to Lady Catherine, “May I ask whether these
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment, or are the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: result of previous study?” These are the things which give Miss Austen’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: readers the pleasant shocks, the delightful thrills, which are felt by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the readers of Swift, of Fielding, and we may here add, of Thackeray, as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they are felt by the readers of no other English author of fiction
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: outside of these four._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _The goodness of the minor characters in_ Pride and Prejudice _has been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: already alluded to, and it makes a detailed dwelling on their beauties
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: difficult in any space, and impossible in this. Mrs. Bennet we have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: glanced at, and it is not easy to say whether she is more exquisitely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: amusing or more horribly true. Much the same may be said of Kitty and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia; but it is not every author, even of genius, who would have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: differentiated with such unerring skill the effects of folly and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: vulgarity of intellect and disposition working upon the common
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: weaknesses of woman at such different ages. With Mary, Miss Austen has
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: taken rather less pains, though she has been even more unkind to her;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not merely in the text, but, as we learn from those interesting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: traditional appendices which Mr. Austen Leigh has given us, in dooming
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her privately to marry “one of Mr. Philips’s clerks.” The habits of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: first copying and then retailing moral sentiments, of playing and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: singing too long in public, are, no doubt, grievous and criminal; but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: perhaps poor Mary was rather the scapegoat of the sins of blue stockings
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in that Fordyce-belectured generation. It is at any rate difficult not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to extend to her a share of the respect and affection (affection and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: respect of a peculiar kind; doubtless), with which one regards Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collins, when she draws the moral of Lydia’s fall. I sometimes wish
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that the exigencies of the story had permitted Miss Austen to unite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: these personages, and thus at once achieve a notable mating and soothe
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: poor Mrs. Bennet’s anguish over the entail._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _The Bingleys and the Gardiners and the Lucases, Miss Darcy and Miss de
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bourgh, Jane, Wickham, and the rest, must pass without special comment,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: further than the remark that Charlotte Lucas (her egregious papa, though
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: delightful, is just a little on the thither side of the line between
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: comedy and farce) is a wonderfully clever study in drab of one kind, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that Wickham (though something of Miss Austen’s hesitation of touch in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dealing with young men appears) is a not much less notable sketch in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drab of another. Only genius could have made Charlotte what she is, yet
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not disagreeable; Wickham what he is, without investing him either with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a cheap Don Juanish attractiveness or a disgusting rascality. But the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hero and the heroine are not tints to be dismissed._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _Darcy has always seemed to me by far the best and most interesting of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Austen’s heroes; the only possible competitor being Henry Tilney,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whose part is so slight and simple that it hardly enters into
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: comparison. It has sometimes, I believe, been urged that his pride is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unnatural at first in its expression and later in its yielding, while
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his falling in love at all is not extremely probable. Here again I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cannot go with the objectors. Darcy’s own account of the way in which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his pride had been pampered, is perfectly rational and sufficient; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing could be, psychologically speaking, a_ causa verior _for its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sudden restoration to healthy conditions than the shock of Elizabeth’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: scornful refusal acting on a nature_ ex hypothesi _generous. Nothing in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: even our author is finer and more delicately touched than the change of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his demeanour at the sudden meeting in the grounds of Pemberley. Had he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been a bad prig or a bad coxcomb, he might have been still smarting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: under his rejection, or suspicious that the girl had come
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: husband-hunting. His being neither is exactly consistent with the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: probable feelings of a man spoilt in the common sense, but not really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: injured in disposition, and thoroughly in love. As for his being in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: love, Elizabeth has given as just an exposition of the causes of that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: phenomenon as Darcy has of the conditions of his unregenerate state,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only she has of course not counted in what was due to her own personal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: charm._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _The secret of that charm many men and not a few women, from Miss Austen
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself downwards, have felt, and like most charms it is a thing rather
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be felt than to be explained. Elizabeth of course belongs to the_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: allegro _or_ allegra _division of the army of Venus. Miss Austen was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always provokingly chary of description in regard to her beauties; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: except the fine eyes, and a hint or two that she had at any rate
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sometimes a bright complexion, and was not very tall, we hear nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: about her looks. But her chief difference from other heroines of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: lively type seems to lie first in her being distinctly clever--almost
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: strong-minded, in the better sense of that objectionable word--and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: secondly in her being entirely destitute of ill-nature for all her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: propensity to tease and the sharpness of her tongue. Elizabeth can give
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at least as good as she gets when she is attacked; but she never
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “scratches,” and she never attacks first. Some of the merest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: obsoletenesses of phrase and manner give one or two of her early
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: speeches a slight pertness, but that is nothing, and when she comes to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: serious business, as in the great proposal scene with Darcy (which is,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as it should be, the climax of the interest of the book), and in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: final ladies’ battle with Lady Catherine, she is unexceptionable. Then
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: too she is a perfectly natural girl. She does not disguise from herself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or anybody that she resents Darcy’s first ill-mannered personality with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as personal a feeling. (By the way, the reproach that the ill-manners of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this speech are overdone is certainly unjust; for things of the same
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: kind, expressed no doubt less stiltedly but more coarsely, might have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been heard in more than one ball-room during this very year from persons
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: who ought to have been no worse bred than Darcy.) And she lets the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: injury done to Jane and the contempt shown to the rest of her family
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: aggravate this resentment in the healthiest way in the world._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _Still, all this does not explain her charm, which, taking beauty as a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: common form of all heroines, may perhaps consist in the addition to her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: playfulness, her wit, her affectionate and natural disposition, of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: certain fearlessness very uncommon in heroines of her type and age.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Nearly all of them would have been in speechless awe of the magnificent
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy; nearly all of them would have palpitated and fluttered at the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: idea of proposals, even naughty ones, from the fascinating Wickham.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, with nothing offensive, nothing_ viraginous, _nothing of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “New Woman” about her, has by nature what the best modern (not “new”)
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: women have by education and experience, a perfect freedom from the idea
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that all men may bully her if they choose, and that most will away with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her if they can. Though not in the least “impudent and mannish grown,”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she has no mere sensibility, no nasty niceness about her. The form of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: passion common and likely to seem natural in Miss Austen’s day was so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: invariably connected with the display of one or the other, or both of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: these qualities, that she has not made Elizabeth outwardly passionate.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But I, at least, have not the slightest doubt that she would have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: married Darcy just as willingly without Pemberley as with it, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anybody who can read between lines will not find the lovers’
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conversations in the final chapters so frigid as they might have looked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to the Della Cruscans of their own day, and perhaps do look to the Della
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Cruscans of this._
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _And, after all, what is the good of seeking for the reason of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: charm?--it is there. There were better sense in the sad mechanic
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exercise of determining the reason of its absence where it is not. In
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the novels of the last hundred years there are vast numbers of young
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ladies with whom it might be a pleasure to fall in love; there are at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: least five with whom, as it seems to me, no man of taste and spirit can
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: help doing so. Their names are, in chronological order, Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet, Diana Vernon, Argemone Lavington, Beatrix Esmond, and Barbara
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Grant. I should have been most in love with Beatrix and Argemone; I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should, I think, for mere occasional companionship, have preferred Diana
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and Barbara. But to live with and to marry, I do not know that any one
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the four can come into competition with Elizabeth._

text: Chapter I.]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the surrounding families, that he is considered as the rightful
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: property of some one or other of their daughters.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My dear Mr. Bennet,” said his lady to him one day, “have you heard that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Netherfield Park is let at last?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But it is,” returned she; “for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: told me all about it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet made no answer.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Do not you want to know who has taken it?” cried his wife, impatiently.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “He came down to see the place”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: This was invitation enough.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in the house by the end of next week.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What is his name?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Bingley.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Is he married or single?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: five thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “How so? how can it affect them?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My dear Mr. Bennet,” replied his wife, “how can you be so tiresome? You
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Is that his design in settling here?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Design? Nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: soon as he comes.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go--or you may send
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better; for as you are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: party.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My dear, you flatter me. I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now. When a woman has five
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: grown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the neighbourhood.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is more than I engage for, I assure you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: merely on that account; for in general, you know, they visit no new
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: comers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for _us_ to visit
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him, if you do not.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are over scrupulous, surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls--though
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: others: and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving _her_ the preference.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “They have none of them much to recommend them,” replied he: “they are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quickness than her sisters.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way? You take
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: delight in vexing me. You have no compassion on my poor nerves.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: are my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: these twenty years at least.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Ah, you do not know what I suffer.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thousand a year come into the neighbourhood.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come, since you will not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visit them.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. _Her_ mind
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was less difficult to develope. She was a woman of mean understanding,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: daughters married: its solace was visiting and news.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: CHAPTER II.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: paid she had no knowledge of it. It was then disclosed in the following
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: manner. Observing his second daughter employed in trimming a hat, he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suddenly addressed her with,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I hope Mr. Bingley will like it, Lizzy.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes,” said her mother,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resentfully, “since we are not to visit.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But you forget, mamma,” said Elizabeth, “that we shall meet him at the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assemblies, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “No more have I,” said Mr. Bennet; “and I am glad to find that you do
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not depend on her serving you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply; but, unable to contain
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself, began scolding one of her daughters.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Don’t keep coughing so, Kitty, for heaven’s sake! Have a little
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: compassion on my nerves. You tear them to pieces.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Kitty has no discretion in her coughs,” said her father; “she times
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them ill.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I do not cough for my own amusement,” replied Kitty, fretfully. “When
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: is your next ball to be, Lizzy?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “To-morrow fortnight.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Ay, so it is,” cried her mother, “and Mrs. Long does not come back till
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the day before; so, it will be impossible for her to introduce him, for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she will not know him herself.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley to _her_.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: myself; how can you be so teasing?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I honour your circumspection. A fortnight’s acquaintance is certainly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fortnight. But if _we_ do not venture, somebody else will; and after
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and, therefore,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: will take it on myself.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet said only, “Nonsense,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nonsense!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?” cried he. “Do
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them, as nonsense? I cannot quite agree with you _there_. What say you,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mary? For you are a young lady of deep reflection, I know, and read
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: great books, and make extracts.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “While Mary is adjusting her ideas,” he continued, “let us return to Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am sick of Mr. Bingley,” cried his wife.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did you not tell me so before? If I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had known as much this morning, I certainly would not have called on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him. It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cannot escape the acquaintance now.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished--that of Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though when the first tumult of joy
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: while.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: persuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: neglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! And it is such a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: word about it till now.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you choose,” said Mr. Bennet; and,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as he spoke, he left the room, fatigued with the raptures of his wife.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What an excellent father you have, girls,” said she, when the door was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shut. “I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or me either, for that matter. At our time of life, it is not so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasant, I can tell you, to be making new acquaintances every day; but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for your sakes we would do anything. Lydia, my love, though you _are_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ball.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh,” said Lydia, stoutly, “I am not afraid; for though I _am_ the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: youngest, I’m the tallest.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon he would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: return Mr. Bennet’s visit, and determining when they should ask him to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dinner.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Not all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: daughters, could ask on the subject, was sufficient to draw from her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: husband any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley. They attacked him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in various ways, with barefaced questions, ingenious suppositions, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: distant surmises; but he eluded the skill of them all; and they were at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: last obliged to accept the second-hand intelligence of their neighbour,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Lucas. Her report was highly favourable. Sir William had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: delighted with him. He was quite young, wonderfully handsome, extremely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: agreeable, and, to crown the whole, he meant to be at the next assembly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with a large party. Nothing could be more delightful! To be fond of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dancing was a certain step towards falling in love; and very lively
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hopes of Mr. Bingley’s heart were entertained.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield,”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, “and all the others equally well
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: married, I shall have nothing to wish for.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In a few days Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet’s visit, and sat about ten
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: minutes with him in his library. He had entertained hopes of being
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: admitted to a sight of the young ladies, of whose beauty he had heard
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much; but he saw only the father. The ladies were somewhat more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fortunate, for they had the advantage of ascertaining, from an upper
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: window, that he wore a blue coat and rode a black horse.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards despatched; and already had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: housekeeping, when an answer arrived which deferred it all. Mr. Bingley
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was obliged to be in town the following day, and consequently unable to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accept the honour of their invitation, etc. Mrs. Bennet was quite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disconcerted. She could not imagine what business he could have in town
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so soon after his arrival in Hertfordshire; and she began to fear that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he might always be flying about from one place to another, and never
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: settled at Netherfield as he ought to be. Lady Lucas quieted her fears a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little by starting the idea of his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “When the Party entered”

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being gone to London only to get a large party for the ball; and a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: report soon followed that Mr. Bingley was to bring twelve ladies and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seven gentlemen with him to the assembly. The girls grieved over such a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: number of ladies; but were comforted the day before the ball by hearing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that, instead of twelve, he had brought only six with him from London,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his five sisters and a cousin. And when the party entered the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assembly-room, it consisted of only five altogether: Mr. Bingley, his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: two sisters, the husband of the eldest, and another young man.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley was good-looking and gentlemanlike: he had a pleasant
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: countenance, and easy, unaffected manners. His sisters were fine women,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with an air of decided fashion. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, merely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looked the gentleman; but his friend Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the room by his fine, tall person, handsome features, noble mien, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the report, which was in general circulation within five minutes after
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his entrance, of his having ten thousand a year. The gentlemen
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pronounced him to be a fine figure of a man, the ladies declared he was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much handsomer than Mr. Bingley, and he was looked at with great
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: admiration for about half the evening, till his manners gave a disgust
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which turned the tide of his popularity; for he was discovered to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: proud, to be above his company, and above being pleased; and not all his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: large estate in Derbyshire could save him from having a most forbidding,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disagreeable countenance, and being unworthy to be compared with his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friend.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley had soon made himself acquainted with all the principal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: people in the room: he was lively and unreserved, danced every dance,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was angry that the ball closed so early, and talked of giving one
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself at Netherfield. Such amiable qualities must speak for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: themselves. What a contrast between him and his friend! Mr. Darcy danced
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, declined being
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: introduced to any other lady, and spent the rest of the evening in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: walking about the room, speaking occasionally to one of his own party.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: His character was decided. He was the proudest, most disagreeable man in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the world, and everybody hoped that he would never come there again.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Amongst the most violent against him was Mrs. Bennet, whose dislike of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: having slighted one of her daughters.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: down for two dances; and during part of that time, Mr. Darcy had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: standing near enough for her to overhear a conversation between him and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley, who came from the dance for a few minutes to press his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friend to join it.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Come, Darcy,” said he, “I must have you dance. I hate to see you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: standing about by yourself in this stupid manner. You had much better
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dance.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I certainly shall not. You know how I detest it, unless I am
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: particularly acquainted with my partner. At such an assembly as this, it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would be insupportable. Your sisters are engaged, and there is not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: another woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to me to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stand up with.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I would not be so fastidious as you are,” cried Bingley, “for a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: kingdom! Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: life as I have this evening; and there are several of them, you see,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uncommonly pretty.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “_You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,” said Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! But there is one
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dare say very agreeable. Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Which do you mean?” and turning round, he looked for a moment at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, till, catching her eye, he withdrew his own, and coldly said,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She is tolerable: but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; and I am in no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: smiles, for you are wasting your time with me.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley followed his advice. Mr. Darcy walked off; and Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: remained with no very cordial feelings towards him. She told the story,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: however, with great spirit among her friends; for she had a lively,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: playful disposition, which delighted in anything ridiculous.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family. Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet had seen her eldest daughter much admired by the Netherfield
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: party. Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and she had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: distinguished by his sisters. Jane was as much gratified by this as her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mother could be, though in a quieter way. Elizabeth felt Jane’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasure. Mary had heard herself mentioned to Miss Bingley as the most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accomplished girl in the neighbourhood; and Catherine and Lydia had been

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When Jane and Elizabeth were alone, the former, who had been cautious in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her praise of Mr. Bingley before, expressed to her sister how very much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she admired him.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “He is just what a young-man ought to be,” said she, “sensible,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners! so much ease,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with such perfect good breeding!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “He is also handsome,” replied Elizabeth, “which a young man ought
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: likewise to be if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: did not expect such a compliment.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Did not you? _I_ did for you. But that is one great difference between
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: us. Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never. What
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could be more natural than his asking you again? He could not help
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the room. No thanks to his gallantry for that. Well, he certainly is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. You have liked many a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stupider person.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Dear Lizzy!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, you are a great deal too apt, you know, to like people in general.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: You never see a fault in anybody. All the world are good and agreeable
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in your eyes. I never heard you speak ill of a human being in my life.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I would wish not to be hasty in censuring anyone; but I always speak
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what I think.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I know you do: and it is _that_ which makes the wonder. With _your_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: others! Affectation of candour is common enough; one meets with it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: everywhere. But to be candid without ostentation or design,--to take the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good of everybody’s character and make it still better, and say nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the bad,--belongs to you alone. And so, you like this man’s sisters,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: too, do you? Their manners are not equal to his.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Certainly not, at first; but they are very pleasing women when you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: converse with them. Miss Bingley is to live with her brother, and keep
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: neighbour in her.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth listened in silence, but was not convinced: their behaviour at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the assembly had not been calculated to please in general; and with more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than her sister, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with a judgment, too, unassailed by any attention to herself, she was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very little disposed to approve them. They were, in fact, very fine
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ladies; not deficient in good-humour when they were pleased, nor in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: power of being agreeable where they chose it; but proud and conceited.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They were rather handsome; had been educated in one of the first private
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seminaries in town; had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds; were in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: habit of spending more than they ought, and of associating with people
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of rank; and were, therefore, in every respect entitled to think well of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: themselves and meanly of others. They were of a respectable family in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the north of England; a circumstance more deeply impressed on their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: memories than that their brother’s fortune and their own had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquired by trade.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thousand pounds from his father, who had intended to purchase an estate,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but did not live to do it. Mr. Bingley intended it likewise, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sometimes made choice of his county; but, as he was now provided with a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good house and the liberty of a manor, it was doubtful to many of those
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: who best knew the easiness of his temper, whether he might not spend the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: remainder of his days at Netherfield, and leave the next generation to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: purchase.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: His sisters were very anxious for his having an estate of his own; but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though he was now established only as a tenant, Miss Bingley was by no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: means unwilling to preside at his table; nor was Mrs. Hurst, who had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: married a man of more fashion than fortune, less disposed to consider
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his house as her home when it suited her. Mr. Bingley had not been of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: age two years when he was tempted, by an accidental recommendation, to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: look at Netherfield House. He did look at it, and into it, for half an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hour; was pleased with the situation and the principal rooms, satisfied
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with what the owner said in its praise, and took it immediately.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Between him and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: great opposition of character. Bingley was endeared to Darcy by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: easiness, openness, and ductility of his temper, though no disposition
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could offer a greater contrast to his own, and though with his own he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: never appeared dissatisfied. On the strength of Darcy’s regard, Bingley
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had the firmest reliance, and of his judgment the highest opinion. In
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: understanding, Darcy was the superior. Bingley was by no means
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: deficient; but Darcy was clever. He was at the same time haughty,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reserved, and fastidious; and his manners, though well bred, were not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inviting. In that respect his friend had greatly the advantage. Bingley
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was sure of being liked wherever he appeared; Darcy was continually
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: giving offence.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The manner in which they spoke of the Meryton assembly was sufficiently
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: characteristic. Bingley had never met with pleasanter people or prettier
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: girls in his life; everybody had been most kind and attentive to him;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there had been no formality, no stiffness; he had soon felt acquainted
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with all the room; and as to Miss Bennet, he could not conceive an angel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: more beautiful. Darcy, on the contrary, had seen a collection of people
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in whom there was little beauty and no fashion, for none of whom he had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: felt the smallest interest, and from none received either attention or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasure. Miss Bennet he acknowledged to be pretty; but she smiled too
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Hurst and her sister allowed it to be so; but still they admired
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her and liked her, and pronounced her to be a sweet girl, and one whom
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they should not object to know more of. Miss Bennet was therefore
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: established as a sweet girl; and their brother felt authorized by such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: commendation to think of her as he chose.

text: Within a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were particularly intimate. Sir William Lucas had been formerly in trade
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in Meryton, where he had made a tolerable fortune, and risen to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: honour of knighthood by an address to the king during his mayoralty. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: distinction had, perhaps, been felt too strongly. It had given him a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disgust to his business and to his residence in a small market town;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and, quitting them both, he had removed with his family to a house about
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a mile from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge; where he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could think with pleasure of his own importance, and, unshackled by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all the world. For,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though elated by his rank, it did not render him supercilious; on the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: contrary, he was all attention to everybody. By nature inoffensive,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friendly, and obliging, his presentation at St. James’s had made him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: courteous.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: valuable neighbour to Mrs. Bennet. They had several children. The eldest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about twenty-seven, was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s intimate friend.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: That the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk over a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the assembly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: self-command, to Miss Lucas. “_You_ were Mr. Bingley’s first choice.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes; but he seemed to like his second better.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “His pride,” said Miss Lucas, “does not offend _me_ so much as pride
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: often does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Pride,” observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reflections, “is a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ourselves; vanity to what we would have others think of us.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The ladies of Longbourn soon waited on those of Netherfield. The visit
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was returned in due form. Miss Bennet’s pleasing manners grew on the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-will of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; and though the mother was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: found to be intolerable, and the younger sisters not worth speaking to,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a wish of being better acquainted with _them_ was expressed towards the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: two eldest. By Jane this attention was received with the greatest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasure; but Elizabeth still saw superciliousness in their treatment of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: everybody, hardly excepting even her sister, and could not like them;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though their kindness to Jane, such as it was, had a value, as arising,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in all probability, from the influence of their brother’s admiration. It
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was generally evident, whenever they met, that he _did_ admire her; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to _her_ it was equally evident that Jane was yielding to the preference
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which she had begun to entertain for him from the first, and was in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: way to be very much in love; but she considered with pleasure that it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was not likely to be discovered by the world in general, since Jane
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: united with great strength of feeling, a composure of temper and an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uniform cheerfulness of manner, which would guard her from the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suspicions of the impertinent. She mentioned this to her friend, Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lucas.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It may, perhaps, be pleasant,” replied Charlotte, “to be able to impose
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on the public in such a case; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so very guarded. If a woman conceals her affection with the same skill
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from the object of it, she may lose the opportunity of fixing him; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dark. There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attachment, that it is not safe to leave any to itself. We can all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _begin_ freely--a slight preference is natural enough; but there are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: encouragement. In nine cases out of ten, a woman had better show _more_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: affection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister undoubtedly; but he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: may never do more than like her, if she does not help him on.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But she does help him on, as much as her nature will allow. If _I_ can
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: perceive her regard for him, he must be a simpleton indeed not to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: discover it too.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane’s disposition as you do.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavor to conceal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it, he must find it out.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her. But though Bingley and Jane
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: meet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and as they
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: every moment should be employed in conversing together. Jane should
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: therefore make the most of every half hour in which she can command his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attention. When she is secure of him, there will be leisure for falling
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in love as much as she chooses.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Occupied in observing Mr. Bingley’s attention to her sister, Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was far from suspecting that she was herself becoming an object of some
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: interest in the eyes of his friend. Mr. Darcy had at first scarcely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: allowed her to be pretty: he had looked at her without admiration at the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ball; and when they next met, he looked at her only to criticise. But no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sooner had he made it clear to himself and his friends that she had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hardly a good feature in her face, than he began to find it was rendered
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of her dark eyes. To
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying. Though he had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: detected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in her form, he was forced to acknowledge her figure to be light and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasing; and in spite of his asserting that her manners were not those
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the fashionable world, he was caught by their easy playfulness. Of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this she was perfectly unaware: to her he was only the man who made
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself agreeable nowhere, and who had not thought her handsome enough
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to dance with.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: He began to wish to know more of her; and, as a step towards conversing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with her himself, attended to her conversation with others. His doing so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drew her notice. It was at Sir William Lucas’s, where a large party were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assembled.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What does Mr. Darcy mean,” said she to Charlotte, “by listening to my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conversation with Colonel Forster?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But if he does it any more, I shall certainly let him know that I see
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.”

text: On his approaching them soon afterwards, though without seeming to have
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: turned to him and said,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: just now, when I was teasing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Meryton?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “With great energy; but it is a subject which always makes a lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: energetic.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are severe on us.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It will be _her_ turn soon to be teased,” said Miss Lucas. “I am going
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!--always wanting me
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to play and sing before anybody and everybody! If my vanity had taken a
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she added, “Very well; if it must be so, it must.” And gravely glancing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at Mr. Darcy, “There is a very fine old saying, which everybody here is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of course familiar with--‘Keep your breath to cool your porridge,’--and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I shall keep mine to swell my song.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Her performance was pleasing, though by no means capital. After a song
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or two, and before she could reply to the entreaties of several that she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would sing again, she was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister Mary, who having, in consequence of being the only plain one in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the family, worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments, was always
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impatient for display.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mary had neither genius nor taste; and though vanity had given her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: application, it had given her likewise a pedantic air and conceited
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: manner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had reached. Elizabeth, easy and unaffected, had been listened to with
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: passing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much engrossed by his own thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was his neighbour, till Sir William thus began:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing like dancing, after all. I consider it as one of the first
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: refinements of polished societies.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Certainly, sir; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the less polished societies of the world: every savage can dance.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Sir William only smiled. “Your friend performs delightfully,” he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: continued, after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; “and I doubt
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you often dance at St. James’s?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Never, sir.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You have a house in town, I conclude?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Darcy bowed.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I had once some thoughts of fixing in town myself, for I am fond of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: London would agree with Lady Lucas.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: He paused in hopes of an answer: but his companion was not disposed to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her,--

text: “My dear Miss Eliza, why are not you dancing? Mr. Darcy, you must allow
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner. You
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cannot refuse to dance, I am sure, when so much beauty is before you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: And, taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy, who, though
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Indeed, sir, I have not the least intention of dancing. I entreat you
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Darcy, with grave propriety, requested to be allowed the honour of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her hand, but in vain. Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for one half hour.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Mr. Darcy is all politeness,” said Elizabeth, smiling.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: partner?”

text: Elizabeth looked archly, and turned away. Her resistance had not injured
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: complacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I can guess the subject of your reverie.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I should imagine not.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: evenings in this manner,--in such society; and, indeed, I am quite of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: your opinion. I was never more annoyed! The insipidity, and yet the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: noise--the nothingness, and yet the self-importance, of all these
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: people! What would I give to hear your strictures on them!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: agreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Darcy replied, with great intrepidity,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Elizabeth Bennet.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Elizabeth Bennet!” repeated Miss Bingley. “I am all astonishment.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: How long has she been such a favourite? and pray when am I to wish you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: joy?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to matrimony, in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Nay, if you are so serious about it, I shall consider the matter as
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of course she will be always at Pemberley with you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice
