text: CHAPTER VII.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet’s property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had left her four thousand pounds.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She had a sister married to a Mr. Philips, who had been a clerk to their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: father and succeeded him in the business, and a brother settled in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: London in a respectable line of trade.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to a milliner’s shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their minds were more vacant than their sisters’, and when nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and, however bare of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: news the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the head-quarters.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Their visits to Mrs. Philips were now productive of the most interesting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: intelligence. Every day added something to their knowledge of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: officers’ names and connections. Their lodgings were not long a secret,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and at length they began to know the officers themselves. Mr. Philips
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visited them all, and this opened to his nieces a source of felicity
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unknown before. They could talk of nothing but officers; and Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley’s large fortune, the mention of which gave animation to their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the regimentals of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: an ensign.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet coolly observed,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I am now convinced.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine was disconcerted, and made no answer; but Lydia, with perfect
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: indifference, continued to express her admiration of Captain Carter, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her hope of seeing him in the course of the day, as he was going the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: next morning to London.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am astonished, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that you should be so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of anybody’s children, it should not be of my own, however.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If my children are silly, I must hope to be always sensible of it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes; but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree. I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: foolish.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My dear Mr. Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their father and mother. When they get to our age, I dare say they will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not think about officers any more than we do. I remember the time when I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: liked a red coat myself very well--and, indeed, so I do still at my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: heart; and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should want one of my girls, I shall not say nay to him; and I thought
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William’s in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his regimentals.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Mamma,” cried Lydia, “my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson’s as they did when they first
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: came; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke’s library.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for an answer. Mrs. Bennet’s eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: eagerly calling out, while her daughter read,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Well, Jane, who is it from? What is it about? What does he say? Well,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is from Miss Bingley,” said Jane, and then read it aloud.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: end without a quarrel. Come as soon as you can on the receipt of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this. My brother and the gentlemen are to dine with the officers.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Yours ever,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “CAROLINE BINGLEY.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “With the officers!” cried Lydia: “I wonder my aunt did not tell us of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _that_.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Can I have the carriage?” said Jane.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rain; and then you must stay all night.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That would be a good scheme,” said Elizabeth, “if you were sure that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they would not offer to send her home.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley’s chaise to go to Meryton;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and the Hursts have no horses to theirs.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I had much rather go in the coach.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure. They are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are not they?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration: Cheerful prognostics]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But if you have got them to-day,” said Elizabeth, “my mother’s purpose
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: will be answered.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She did at last extort from her father an acknowledgment that the horses
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were engaged; Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback, and her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mother attended her to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: day. Her hopes were answered; Jane had not been gone long before it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rained hard. Her sisters were uneasy for her, but her mother was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: delighted. The rain continued the whole evening without intermission;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane certainly could not come back.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!” said Mrs. Bennet, more than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: once, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own. Till the next
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: morning, however, she was not aware of all the felicity of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: contrivance. Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: brought the following note for Elizabeth:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: /* NIND “My dearest Lizzie, */
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: imputed to my getting wet through yesterday. My kind friends will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not hear of my returning home till I am better. They insist also on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my seeing Mr. Jones--therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of his having been to me--and, excepting a sore throat and a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: headache, there is not much the matter with me.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yours, etc.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Well, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: aloud, “if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness--if she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should die--it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley, and under your orders.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, I am not at all afraid of her dying. People do not die of little
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: trifling colds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there, it is all very well. I would go and see her if I could have the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: carriage.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, feeling really anxious, determined to go to her, though the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: carriage was not to be had: and as she was no horsewoman, walking was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her only alternative. She declared her resolution.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “How can you be so silly,” cried her mother, “as to think of such a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I shall be very fit to see Jane--which is all I want.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,” said her father, “to send for the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: horses?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “No, indeed. I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I admire the activity of your benevolence,” observed Mary, “but every
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exertion should always be in proportion to what is required.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “We will go as far as Meryton with you,” said Catherine and Lydia.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: together.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If we make haste,” said Lydia, as they walked along, “perhaps we may
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: see something of Captain Carter, before he goes.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In Meryton they parted: the two youngest repaired to the lodgings of one
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the officers’ wives, and Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: field after field at a quick pace, jumping over stiles and springing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: over puddles, with impatient activity, and finding herself at last
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: within view of the house, with weary ancles, dirty stockings, and a face
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: glowing with the warmth of exercise.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She was shown into the breakfast parlour, where all but Jane were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assembled, and where her appearance created a great deal of surprise.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: That she should have walked three miles so early in the day in such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dirty weather, and by herself, was almost incredible to Mrs. Hurst and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Bingley; and Elizabeth was convinced that they held her in contempt
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for it. She was received, however, very politely by them; and in their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: brother’s manners there was something better than politeness--there was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-humour and kindness. Mr. Darcy said very little, and Mr. Hurst
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing at all. The former was divided between admiration of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: brilliancy which exercise had given to her complexion and doubt as to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the occasion’s justifying her coming so far alone. The latter was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thinking only of his breakfast.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Her inquiries after her sister were not very favourably answered. Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet had slept ill, and though up, was very feverish, and not well
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enough to leave her room. Elizabeth was glad to be taken to her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: immediately; and Jane, who had only been withheld by the fear of giving
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: alarm or inconvenience, from expressing in her note how much she longed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for such a visit, was delighted at her entrance. She was not equal,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: however, to much conversation; and when Miss Bingley left them together,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could attempt little beside expressions of gratitude for the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: extraordinary kindness she was treated with. Elizabeth silently attended
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When breakfast was over, they were joined by the sisters; and Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: began to like them herself, when she saw how much affection and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: solicitude they showed for Jane. The apothecary came; and having
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: examined his patient, said, as might be supposed, that she had caught a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: violent cold, and that they must endeavour to get the better of it;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: advised her to return to bed, and promised her some draughts. The advice
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was followed readily, for the feverish symptoms increased, and her head
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ached acutely. Elizabeth did not quit her room for a moment, nor were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the other ladies often absent; the gentlemen being out, they had in fact
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing to do elsewhere.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt that she must go, and very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unwillingly said so. Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, and she only
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wanted a little pressing to accept it, when Jane testified such concern
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at parting with her that Miss Bingley was obliged to convert the offer
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the chaise into an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: present. Elizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: despatched to Longbourn, to acquaint the family with her stay, and bring
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: back a supply of clothes.

text: At five o’clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was summoned to dinner. To the civil inquiries which then
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: poured in, and amongst which she had the pleasure of distinguishing the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much superior solicitude of Mr. Bingley, she could not make a very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: favourable answer. Jane was by no means better. The sisters, on hearing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this, repeated three or four times how much they were grieved, how
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shocking it was to have a bad cold, and how excessively they disliked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being ill themselves; and then thought no more of the matter: and their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: indifference towards Jane, when not immediately before them, restored
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth to the enjoyment of all her original dislike.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Their brother, indeed, was the only one of the party whom she could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regard with any complacency. His anxiety for Jane was evident, and his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attentions to herself most pleasing; and they prevented her feeling
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself so much an intruder as she believed she was considered by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: others. She had very little notice from any but him. Miss Bingley was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: engrossed by Mr. Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Hurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: eat, drink, and play at cards, who, when he found her prefer a plain
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: began abusing her as soon as she was out of the room. Her manners were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pronounced to be very bad indeed,--a mixture of pride and impertinence:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she had no conversation, no style, no taste, no beauty. Mrs. Hurst
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thought the same, and added,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: walker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looked almost wild.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She did indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nonsensical to come at all! Why must _she_ be scampering about the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: country, because her sister had a cold? Her hair so untidy, so blowzy!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in mud, I am absolutely certain, and the gown which had been let down to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hide it not doing its office.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Your picture may be very exact, Louisa,” said Bingley; “but this was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all lost upon me. I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably well
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when she came into the room this morning. Her dirty petticoat quite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: escaped my notice.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “_You_ observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley; “and I am
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inclined to think that you would not wish to see _your sister_ make such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: an exhibition.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Certainly not.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: above her ancles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! what could she mean by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it? It seems to me to show an abominable sort of conceited independence,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a most country-town indifference to decorum.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It shows an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,” said
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am afraid, Mr. Darcy,” observed Miss Bingley, in a half whisper,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “that this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: eyes.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Not at all,” he replied: “they were brightened by the exercise.” A
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: short pause followed this speech, and Mrs. Hurst began again,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet,--she is really a very sweet
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: girl,--and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: chance of it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I think I have heard you say that their uncle is an attorney in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Meryton?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is capital,” added her sister; and they both laughed heartily.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If they had uncles enough to fill _all_ Cheapside,” cried Bingley, “it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would not make them one jot less agreeable.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: consideration in the world,” replied Darcy.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: To this speech Bingley made no answer; but his sisters gave it their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hearty assent, and indulged their mirth for some time at the expense of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their dear friend’s vulgar relations.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: With a renewal of tenderness, however, they repaired to her room on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: leaving the dining-parlour, and sat with her till summoned to coffee.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She was still very poorly, and Elizabeth would not quit her at all, till
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: late in the evening, when she had the comfort of seeing her asleep, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when it appeared to her rather right than pleasant that she should go
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: down stairs herself. On entering the drawing-room, she found the whole
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: party at loo, and was immediately invited to join them; but suspecting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them to be playing high, she declined it, and making her sister the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: excuse, said she would amuse herself, for the short time she could stay
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: below, with a book. Mr. Hurst looked at her with astonishment.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Do you prefer reading to cards?” said he; “that is rather singular.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, “despises cards. She is a great
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reader, and has no pleasure in anything else.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I deserve neither such praise nor such censure,” cried Elizabeth; “I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: am _not_ a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I hope it will soon be increased by seeing her quite well.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth thanked him from her heart, and then walked towards a table
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: where a few books were lying. He immediately offered to fetch her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: others; all that his library afforded.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And I wish my collection were larger for your benefit and my own
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: credit; but I am an idle fellow; and though I have not many, I have more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than I ever looked into.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth assured him that she could suit herself perfectly with those
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in the room.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am astonished,” said Miss Bingley, “that my father should have left
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so small a collection of books. What a delightful library you have at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Pemberley, Mr. Darcy!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It ought to be good,” he replied: “it has been the work of many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: generations.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And then you have added so much to it yourself--you are always buying
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: books.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I cannot comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: these.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Neglect! I am sure you neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that noble place. Charles, when you build _your_ house, I wish it may be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: half as delightful as Pemberley.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I wish it may.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But I would really advise you to make your purchase in that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: neighbourhood, and take Pemberley for a kind of model. There is not a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: finer county in England than Derbyshire.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “With all my heart: I will buy Pemberley itself, if Darcy will sell it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am talking of possibilities, Charles.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was so much caught by what passed, as to leave her very little
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attention for her book; and, soon laying it wholly aside, she drew near
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his eldest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister, to observe the game.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley: “will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she be as tall as I am?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet’s height, or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rather taller.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so much. Such a countenance, such manners, and so extremely accomplished
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for her age! Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young ladies can have patience
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be so very accomplished as they all are.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover screens, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: net purses. I scarcely know any one who cannot do all this; and I am
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sure I never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being informed that she was very accomplished.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen; but I am very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen in the whole range of my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance that are really accomplished.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: idea of an accomplished woman.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes; I do comprehend a great deal in it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, certainly,” cried his faithful assistant, “no one can be really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: esteemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and, besides all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: will be but half deserved.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “All this she must possess,” added Darcy; “and to all she must yet add
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: something more substantial in the improvement of her mind by extensive
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reading.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished women.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I rather wonder now at your knowing _any_.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Are you so severe upon your own sex as to doubt the possibility of all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “_I_ never saw such a woman. _I_ never saw such capacity, and taste, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: application, and elegance, as you describe, united.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: room.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her, “is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I daresay, it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: succeeds; but, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “there is meanness in _all_ the arts which ladies sometimes condescend
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: despicable.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: continue the subject.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that she could not leave her. Bingley urged Mr. Jones’s being sent for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: immediately; while his sisters, convinced that no country advice could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unwilling to comply with their brother’s proposal; and it was settled
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Miss Bennet
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were not decidedly better. Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: declared that they were miserable. They solaced their wretchedness,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: however, by duets after supper; while he could find no better relief to
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in her sister’s room, and in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sisters. In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: own judgment of her situation. The note was immediately despatched, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its contents as quickly complied with. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Had she found Jane in any apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very miserable; but being satisfied on seeing her that her illness was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not alarming, she had no wish of her recovering immediately, as her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: restoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield. She
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would not listen, therefore, to her daughter’s proposal of being carried
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: home; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it at all advisable. After sitting a little while with Jane, on Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley’s appearance and invitation, the mother and three daughters all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attended her into the breakfast parlour. Bingley met them with hopes
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that Mrs. Bennet had not found Miss Bennet worse than she expected.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Indeed I have, sir,” was her answer. “She is a great deal too ill to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: moved. Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her. We must trespass
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a little longer on your kindness.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Removed!” cried Bingley. “It must not be thought of. My sister, I am
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sure, will not hear of her removal.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You may depend upon it, madam,” said Miss Bingley, with cold civility,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: remains with us.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet was profuse in her acknowledgments.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am sure,” she added, “if it was not for such good friends, I do not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: know what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: temper I ever met with. I often tell my other girls they are nothing to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _her_. You have a sweet room here, Mr. Bingley, and a charming prospect
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: over that gravel walk. I do not know a place in the country that is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: equal to Netherfield. You will not think of quitting it in a hurry, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hope, though you have but a short lease.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Whatever I do is done in a hurry,” replied he; “and therefore if I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: minutes. At present, however, I consider myself as quite fixed here.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elizabeth.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You begin to comprehend me, do you?” cried he, turning towards her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh yes--I understand you perfectly.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I wish I might take this for a compliment; but to be so easily seen
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: through, I am afraid, is pitiful.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is as it happens. It does not necessarily follow that a deep,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: intricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as yours.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Lizzy,” cried her mother, “remember where you are, and do not run on in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I did not know before,” continued Bingley, immediately, “that you were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a studier of character. It must be an amusing study.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes; but intricate characters are the _most_ amusing. They have at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: least that advantage.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “The country,” said Darcy, “can in general supply but few subjects for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: such a study. In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unvarying society.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But people themselves alter so much, that there is something new to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: observed in them for ever.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, indeed,” cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning a
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: going on in the country as in town.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Everybody was surprised; and Darcy, after looking at her for a moment,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: turned silently away. Mrs. Bennet, who fancied she had gained a complete
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: victory over him, continued her triumph,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country, for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasanter, is not it, Mr. Bingley?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “When I am in the country,” he replied, “I never wish to leave it; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when I am in town, it is pretty much the same. They have each their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: advantages, and I can be equally happy in either.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Ay, that is because you have the right disposition. But that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gentleman,” looking at Darcy, “seemed to think the country was nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at all.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mother. “You quite mistook Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there was not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: such a variety of people to be met with in the country as in town, which
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: countenance. His sister was less delicate, and directed her eye towards
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Charlotte so _very_ plain; but then she is our particular friend.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She seems a very pleasant young woman,” said Bingley.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh dear, yes; but you must own she is very plain. Lady Lucas herself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: has often said so, and envied me Jane’s beauty. I do not like to boast
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: book! When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: an excellent library.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing about it.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at!” cried Elizabeth. “That is an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be a great loss to _me_ to have many such acquaintance. I dearly love a
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Bingley,” said he, “has given me credit for more than can be. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: joke.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you are without.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: understanding to ridicule.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Such as vanity and pride.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride--where there is a real
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: superiority of mind--pride will be always under good regulation.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In consequence of an agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: next morning to her mother, to beg that the carriage might be sent for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them in the course of the day. But Mrs. Bennet, who had calculated on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her daughters remaining at Netherfield till the following Tuesday, which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would exactly finish Jane’s week, could not bring herself to receive
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them with pleasure before. Her answer, therefore, was not propitious, at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: least not to Elizabeth’s wishes, for she was impatient to get home. Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet sent them word that they could not possibly have the carriage
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before Tuesday; and in her postscript it was added, that if Mr. Bingley
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and his sister pressed them to stay longer, she could spare them very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: well. Against staying longer, however, Elizabeth was positively
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resolved--nor did she much expect it would be asked; and fearful, on the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: contrary, of being considered as intruding themselves needlessly long,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley’s carriage immediately, and at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: length it was settled that their original design of leaving Netherfield
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that morning should be mentioned, and the request made.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The communication excited many professions of concern; and enough was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: said of wishing them to stay at least till the following day to work on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane; and till the morrow their going was deferred. Miss Bingley was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: then sorry that she had proposed the delay; for her jealousy and dislike
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of one sister much exceeded her affection for the other.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The master of the house heard with real sorrow that they were to go so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: soon, and repeatedly tried to persuade Miss Bennet that it would not be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: safe for her--that she was not enough recovered; but Jane was firm where
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she felt herself to be right.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: To Mr. Darcy it was welcome intelligence: Elizabeth had been at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Netherfield long enough. She attracted him more than he liked; and Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley was uncivil to _her_ and more teasing than usual to himself. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should _now_ escape him--nothing that could elevate her with the hope of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: influencing his felicity; sensible that, if such an idea had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in confirming or crushing it. Steady to his purpose, he scarcely spoke
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ten words to her through the whole of Saturday: and though they were at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: one time left by themselves for half an hour, he adhered most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conscientiously to his book, and would not even look at her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: On Sunday, after morning service, the separation, so agreeable to almost
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all, took place. Miss Bingley’s civility to Elizabeth increased at last
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very rapidly, as well as her affection for Jane; and when they parted,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: after assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: see her either at Longbourn or Netherfield, and embracing her most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: tenderly, she even shook hands with the former. Elizabeth took leave of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the whole party in the liveliest spirits.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They were not welcomed home very cordially by their mother. Mrs. Bennet
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wondered at their coming, and thought them very wrong to give so much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: trouble, and was sure Jane would have caught cold again. But their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: father, though very laconic in his expressions of pleasure, was really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: glad to see them; he had felt their importance in the family circle. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: evening conversation, when they were all assembled, had lost much of its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: animation, and almost all its sense, by the absence of Jane and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I hope, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: breakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming, I am sure,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in; and I hope _my_ dinners
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: are good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “The person of whom I speak is a gentleman and a stranger.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to-day. Lydia, my love, ring the bell. I must speak to Hill this
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: This roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: explained:--“About a month ago I received this letter, and about a
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and requiring early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when I am dead, may turn you all out of this house as soon as he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleases.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, my dear,” cried his wife, “I cannot bear to hear that mentioned.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet was beyond the reach of reason; and she continued to rail
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Dear Sir,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: father always gave me much uneasiness; and, since I have had the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: breach: but, for some time, I was kept back by my own doubts,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased him to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at variance.”--‘There, Mrs. Bennet.’--“My mind, however, is now
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: made up on the subject; for, having received ordination at Easter,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has preferred me to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be my earnest
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which are instituted by the Church of England. As a clergyman,
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of peace in all families within the reach of my influence; and on
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: means of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself. He was a tall,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: heavy-looking young man of five-and-twenty. His air was grave and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stately, and his manners were very formal. He had not been long seated
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: daughters, said he had heard much of their beauty, but that, in this
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doubt her seeing them all in due time well disposed of in marriage. This
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet, who quarrelled with no compliments, answered most readily,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are very kind, sir, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prove so; for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: oddly.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Ah, sir, I do indeed. It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must confess. Not that I mean to find fault with _you_, for such things,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I know, are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: will go when once they come to be entailed.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: forward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prepared to admire them. At present I will not say more, but, perhaps,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when we are better acquainted----”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the girls smiled on each
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other. They were not the only objects of Mr. Collins’s admiration. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and his commendation of everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: own future property. The dinner, too, in its turn, was highly admired;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and he begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellence of its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cookery was owing. But here he was set right by Mrs. Bennet, who assured
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pardon for having displeased her. In a softened tone she declared
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: CHAPTER XIV
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: During dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness. Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine de Bourgh’s attention to his wishes, and consideration for his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: comfort, appeared very remarkable. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: better. Mr. Collins was eloquent in her praise. The subject elevated him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to more than usual solemnity of manner; and with a most important aspect
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he protested that he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: person of rank--such affability and condescension, as he had himself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: experienced from Lady Catherine. She had been graciously pleased to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: approve of both the discourses which he had already had the honour of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: preaching before her. She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quadrille in the evening. Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: people, he knew, but _he_ had never seen anything but affability in her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: neighbourhood, nor to his leaving his parish occasionally for a week or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: two to visit his relations. She had even condescended to advise him to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to suggest some herself,--some shelves in the closets upstairs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from Rosings Park, her Ladyship’s residence.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I think you said she was a widow, sir? has she any family?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She has one only daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: extensive property.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Ah,” cried Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: many girls. And what sort of young lady is she? Is she handsome?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She is a most charming young lady, indeed. Lady Catherine herself says
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: handsomest of her sex; because there is that in her features which marks
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the young woman of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: constitution, which has prevented her making that progress in many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accomplishments which she could not otherwise have failed of, as I am
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: court.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine myself one day, has deprived
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the British Court of its brightest ornament. Her Ladyship seemed pleased
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess; and that the most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her. These are the kind of little things which please her Ladyship, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pay.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You judge very properly,” said Mr. Bennet; “and it is happy for you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: moment, or are the result of previous study?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time; and though I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: give them as unstudied an air as possible.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet’s expectations were fully answered. His cousin was as absurd
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as he had hoped; and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in his pleasure.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me, I confess; for certainly there can be nothing so advantageous to
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Collins was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had merely kept the necessary terms without forming at it any useful
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance. The subjection in which his father had brought him up had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: given him originally great humility of manner; but it was now a good
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: deal counteracted by the self-conceit of a weak head, living in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: retirement, and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prosperity. A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: This was his plan of amends--of atonement--for inheriting their father’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: estate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: part.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: His plan did not vary on seeing them. Miss Bennet’s lovely face
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was due to seniority; and for the first evening _she_ was his settled
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: choice. The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a quarter
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of an hour’s _tête-à-tête_ with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast, a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress for it might be found at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Longbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: encouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on. “As to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her _younger_ daughters, she could not take upon her to say--she could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not positively answer--but she did not _know_ of any prepossession;--her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _eldest_ daughter she must just mention--she felt it incumbent on her to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth--and it was soon
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: done--done while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire. Elizabeth, equally
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: next to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the day before, was now high in her good graces.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten: every sister
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: except Mary agreed to go with her; and Mr. Collins was to attend them,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him after breakfast, and there he would continue, nominally engaged with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford. Such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doings discomposed Mr. Bennet exceedingly. In his library he had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: house, he was used to be free from them there: his civility, therefore,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than a reader, was extremely well pleased to close his large book, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: go.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cousins, their time passed till they entered Meryton. The attention of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by _him_. Their eyes
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were immediately wandering up the street in quest of the officers, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a shop window, could recall them.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for it, was able to assure her, with tolerable firmness, that the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prospect of their relationship was highly grateful to her, and that she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wished her all imaginable happiness.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I see what you are feeling,” replied Charlotte; “you must be surprised,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very much surprised, so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry you.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But when you have had time to think it all over, I hope you will be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: satisfied with what I have done. I am not romantic, you know. I never
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was. I ask only a comfortable home; and, considering Mr. Collins’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: character, connections, and situation in life, I am convinced that my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: chance of happiness with him is as fair as most people can boast on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: entering the marriage state.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth quietly answered “undoubtedly;” and, after an awkward pause,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they returned to the rest of the family. Charlotte did not stay much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: longer; and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard. It
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was a long time before she became at all reconciled to the idea of so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unsuitable a match. The strangeness of Mr. Collins’s making two offers
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of marriage within three days was nothing in comparison of his being now
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accepted. She had always felt that Charlotte’s opinion of matrimony was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not exactly like her own; but she could not have supposed it possible
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that, when called into action, she would have sacrificed every better
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feeling to worldly advantage. Charlotte, the wife of Mr. Collins, was a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: most humiliating picture! And to the pang of a friend disgracing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself, and sunk in her esteem, was added the distressing conviction
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that it was impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she had chosen.
