text: Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorized to mention it,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: announce her engagement to the family. With many compliments to them,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: houses, he unfolded the matter,--to an audience not merely wondering,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but incredulous; for Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: politeness, protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unguarded and often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Good Lord! Sir William, how can you tell such a story? Do not you know
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: without anger such treatment: but Sir William’s good-breeding carried
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: most forbearing courtesy.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet was, in fact, too much overpowered to say a great deal while
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: found a rapid vent. In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that Mr. Collins
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be happy
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: together; and, fourthly, that the match might be broken off. Two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was the real cause of all the mischief; and the other, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she herself had been barbarously used by them all; and on these two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day. Nothing could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: console and nothing appease her. Nor did that day wear out her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resentment. A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: scolding her: a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or Lady Lucas without being rude; and many months were gone before she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could at all forgive their daughter.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: more foolish than his daughter!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane confessed herself a little surprised at the match: but she said
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: less of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable. Kitty and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to spread at Meryton.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though Mrs. Bennet’s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enough to drive happiness away.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and exceedingly troublesome. She hated having visitors in the house
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: absence.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject. Day after
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Even Elizabeth began to fear--not that Bingley was indifferent--but that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his sisters would be successful in keeping him away. Unwilling as she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was to admit an idea so destructive to Jane’s happiness, and so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dishonourable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: frequently recurring. The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy and the amusements of London, might be too much, she feared, for
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As for Jane, _her_ anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: painful than Elizabeth’s: but whatever she felt she was desirous of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: concealing; and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was never alluded to. But as no such delicacy restrained her mother, an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity, Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Saturday. The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: side by preparations for the reception of his bride, as he had reason to
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: another letter of thanks.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: On the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: brother and his wife, who came, as usual, to spend the Christmas at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Longbourn. Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: superior to his sister, as well by nature as education. The Netherfield
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: well-bred and agreeable. Mrs. Gardiner, who was several years younger
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: woman, and a great favourite with her Longbourn nieces. Between the two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: eldest and herself especially, there subsisted a very particular regard.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They had frequently been staying with her in town.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The first part of Mrs. Gardiner’s business, on her arrival, was to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: distribute her presents and describe the newest fashions. When this was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: done, she had a less active part to play. It became her turn to listen.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of. They
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister. Two of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: girls had been on the point of marriage, and after all there was nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in it.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley if she could. But, Lizzy! Oh, sister! it is very hard to think
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that she might have been Mr. Collins’s wife by this time, had not it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been for her own perverseness. He made her an offer in this very room,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and she refused him. The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a daughter married before I have, and that Longbourn estate is just as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much entailed as ever. The Lucases are very artful people, indeed,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister. They are all for what they can get. I am sorry to say it of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them, but so it is. It makes me very nervous and poorly, to be thwarted
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so in my own family, and to have neighbours who think of themselves
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before anybody else. However, your coming just at this time is the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: greatest of comforts, and I am very glad to hear what you tell us of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: long sleeves.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she. “I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: am sorry it went off. But these things happen so often! A young man,
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: girl for a few weeks, and, when accident separates them, so easily
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: forgets her, that these sort of inconstancies are very frequent.”

text: “An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth; “but it will not
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: love with only a few days before.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But that expression of ‘violently in love’ is so hackneyed, so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doubtful, so indefinite, that it gives me very little idea. It is as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: often applied to feelings which arise only from a half hour’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley’s love?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they met, it was more decided and remarkable. At his own ball he
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would have laughed yourself out of it sooner. But do you think she would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be prevailed on to go back with us? Change of scene might be of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: service--and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anything.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her sister’s ready acquiescence.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Gardiner’s caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone: after
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: openly. Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: yourself, or endeavour to involve him, in an affection which the want of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _him_: he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it is--you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: expect you to use it. Your father would depend on _your_ resolution and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good conduct, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, and I hope to engage you to be serious likewise.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Well, then, you need not be under any alarm. I will take care of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: myself, and of Mr. Wickham too. He shall not be in love with me, if I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: can prevent it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I beg your pardon. I will try again. At present I am not in love with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Wickham; no, I certainly am not. But he is, beyond all comparison,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the most agreeable man I ever saw--and if he becomes really attached to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me--I believe it will be better that he should not. I see the imprudence
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of it. Oh, _that_ abominable Mr. Darcy! My father’s opinion of me does
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me the greatest honour; and I should be miserable to forfeit it. My
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: father, however, is partial to Mr. Wickham. In short, my dear aunt, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: since we see, every day, that where there is affection young people are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seldom withheld, by immediate want of fortune, from entering into
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of my fellow-creatures, if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it would be wiser to resist? All that I can promise you, therefore, is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not to be in a hurry. I will not be in a hurry to believe myself his
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: upstairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her. She opened
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the door, and met Maria in the landing-place, who, breathless with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: agitation, cried out,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “In Conversation with the ladies”

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: haste, and come down this moment.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and down they ran into the dining-room which fronted the lane, in quest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of this wonder; it was two ladies, stopping in a low phaeton at the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: garden gate.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And is this all?” cried Elizabeth. “I expected at least that the pigs
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: daughter!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other is Miss De Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: creature. Who would have thought she could be so thin and small!”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Why does she not come in?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when Miss De Bourgh comes in.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas. “She
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looks sickly and cross. Yes, she will do for him very well. She will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: make him a very proper wife.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth’s high diversion, was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss De Bourgh looked that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: way.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: At length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the others returned into the house. Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to dine at Rosings the next day.

text: CHAPTER XXIX.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Collins’s triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doing it should be given so soon was such an instance of Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine’s condescension as he knew not how to admire enough.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her Ladyship’s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at Rosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it would happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this?
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Who could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there (an invitation, moreover, including the whole party) so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: immediately after your arrival?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the court, such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Scarcely anything was talked of the whole day or next morning but their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visit to Rosings. Mr. Collins was carefully instructing them in what
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they were to expect, that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so splendid a dinner, might not wholly overpower them.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: becomes herself and daughter. I would advise you merely to put on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest--there is no occasion
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for anything more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: preserved.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: objected to be kept waiting for her dinner. Such formidable accounts of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her Ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: who had been little used to company; and she looked forward to her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to his presentation at St. James’s.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As the weather was fine, they had a pleasant walk of about half a mile
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: across the park. Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: raptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria’s alarm was every moment
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s courage did not fail her. She had heard nothing of Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money and rank she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thought she could witness without trepidation.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: From the entrance hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rapturous air, the fine proportion and finished ornaments, they followed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the servants through an antechamber to the room where Lady Catherine,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were sitting. Her Ladyship, with great
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had settled it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with her husband that the office of introduction should be hers, it was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: performed in a proper manner, without any of those apologies and thanks
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which he would have thought necessary.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In spite of having been at St. James’s, Sir William was so completely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her chair, not knowing which way to look. Elizabeth found herself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: composedly. Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: features, which might once have been handsome. Her air was not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visitors forget their inferior rank. She was not rendered formidable by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: silence: but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marked her self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s mind; and, from the observation of the day altogether, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: believed Lady Catherine to be exactly what he had represented.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, she turned her eyes on the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: daughter, she could almost have joined in Maria’s astonishment at her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being so thin and so small. There was neither in figure nor face any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: likeness between the ladies. Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly: her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: features, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little, except in a low voice, to Mrs. Jenkinson, in whose appearance
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her eyes.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: admire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looking at in the summer.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and all the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her Ladyship’s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing greater. He carved and ate and praised with delighted alacrity;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and every dish was commended first by him, and then by Sir William, who
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law said, in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear. But Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and gave most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved a novelty
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to them. The party did not supply much conversation. Elizabeth was ready
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated between
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh--the former of whom was engaged in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the dinnertime. Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little Miss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fearing she was indisposed. Maria thought speaking out of the question,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: intermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: subject in so decisive a manner as proved that she was not used to have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her judgment controverted. She inquired into Charlotte’s domestic
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: concerns familiarly and minutely, and gave her a great deal of advice as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: care of her cows and her poultry. Elizabeth found that nothing was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: beneath this great lady’s attention which could furnish her with an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: occasion for dictating to others. In the intervals of her discourse with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the least, and who, she observed to Mrs. Collins, was a very genteel,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pretty kind of girl. She asked her at different times how many sisters
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mother’s maiden name? Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: questions, but answered them very composedly. Lady Catherine then
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: observed,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Your father’s estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think? For your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: occasion for entailing estates from the female line. It was not thought
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh’s family. Do you play and sing, Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “A little.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh then--some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: instrument is a capital one, probably superior to ---- you shall try it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some day. Do your sisters play and sing?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “One of them does.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Why did not you all learn? You ought all to have learned. The Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours. Do
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you draw?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “No, not at all.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What, none of you?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Not one.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My mother would have no objection, but my father hates London.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Has your governess left you?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “We never had any governess.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: without a governess! I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: have been quite a slave to your education.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth could hardly help smiling, as she assured her that had not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been the case.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Then who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess, you must
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: have been neglected.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wished to learn never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: read, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: idle certainly might.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Ay, no doubt: but that is what a governess will prevent; and if I had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: one. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: way. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was but the other day that I recommended another young person, who
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: delighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalfe’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: calling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure. ‘Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine,’ said she, ‘you have given me a treasure.’ Are any of your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, ma’am, all.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “All! What, all five out at once? Very odd! And you only the second. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: younger ones out before the elder are married! Your younger sisters must
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be very young?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps _she_ is full young to be much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in company. But really, ma’am, I think it would be very hard upon
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: younger sisters that they should not have their share of society and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marry early. The last born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as the first. And to be kept back on _such_ a motive! I think it would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Upon my word,” said her Ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for so young a person. Pray, what is your age?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure,--therefore you need not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conceal your age.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am not one-and-twenty.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card tables
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were placed. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: down to quadrille; and as Miss De Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: two girls had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: party. Their table was superlatively stupid. Scarcely a syllable was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: expressed her fears of Miss De Bourgh’s being too hot or too cold, or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: having too much or too little light. A great deal more passed at the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other table. Lady Catherine was generally speaking--stating the mistakes
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself. Mr. Collins
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was employed in agreeing to everything her Ladyship said, thanking her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for every fish he won, and apologizing if he thought he won too many.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Sir William did not say much. He was storing his memory with anecdotes
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and noble names.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gratefully accepted, and immediately ordered. The party then gathered
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: round the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to have on the morrow. From these instructions they were summoned by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collins’s side, and as many bows on Sir William’s, they departed. As
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: soon as they had driven from the door, Elizabeth was called on by her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cousin to give her opinion of all that she had seen at Rosings, which,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for Charlotte’s sake, she made more favourable than it really was. But
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her commendation, though costing her some trouble, could by no means
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: satisfy Mr. Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take her Ladyship’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: praise into his own hands.

text: CHAPTER XXX.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford; but his visit was long
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enough to convince him of his daughter’s being most comfortably settled,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: often met with. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mornings to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country: but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cousin by the alteration; for the chief of the time between breakfast
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden, or in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reading and writing, and looking out of window in his own book room,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which fronted the road. The room in which the ladies sat was backwards.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth at first had rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the dining parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasanter aspect: but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much less in his own apartment had they sat in one equally lively; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: along, and how often especially Miss De Bourgh drove by in her phaeton,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: almost every day. She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a few minutes’ conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prevailed on to get out.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hours. Now and then they were honoured with a call from her Ladyship,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: these visits. She examined into their employments, looked at their work,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the furniture, or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: out that Mrs. Collins’s joints of meat were too large for her family.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: commission of the peace for the county, she was a most active magistrate
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them into harmony and plenty.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “he never failed to inform them”

text: The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine’s curiosity.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In this quiet way the first fortnight of her visit soon passed away.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Easter was approaching, and the week preceding it was to bring an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: addition to the family at Rosings, which in so small a circle must be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: important. Elizabeth had heard, soon after her arrival, that Mr. Darcy
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was expected there in the course of a few weeks; and though there were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not many of her acquaintance whom she did not prefer, his coming would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she might be amused in seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley’s designs on him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently destined
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: by Lady Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: satisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Lucas and herself.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friend, met her with every appearance of composure. Elizabeth merely
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly, with the
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners were very much admired at the Parsonage,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and the ladies all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasure of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their engagements at Rosings. It was some days, however, before they
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: received any invitation thither, for while there were visitors in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: house they could not be necessary; and it was not till Easter-day,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: almost a week after the gentlemen’s arrival, that they were honoured by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: such an attention, and then they were merely asked on leaving church to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: come there in the evening. For the last week they had seen very little
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of either Lady Catherine or her daughter. Colonel Fitzwilliam had called
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at the Parsonage more than once during the time, but Mr. Darcy they had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only seen at church.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The invitation was accepted, of course, and at a proper hour they joined
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the party in Lady Catherine’s drawing-room. Her Ladyship received them
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: almost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much more than to any other person in the room.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them: anything was a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: welcome relief to him at Rosings; and Mrs. Collins’s pretty friend had,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: moreover, caught his fancy very much. He now seated himself by her, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at home, of new books and music, that Elizabeth had never been half so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: well entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: spirit and flow as to draw the attention of Lady Catherine herself, as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: well as of Mr. Darcy. _His_ eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her Ladyship, after a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: scruple to call out,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “We were talking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a reply.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must have my share in the conversation, if you are speaking of music.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enjoyment of music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: learnt, I should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: health had allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: performed delightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister’s proficiency.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: if she does not practise a great deal.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She practises very constantly.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: tell young ladies, that no excellence in music is to be acquired without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: constant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: never play really well, unless she practises more; and though Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jenkinson’s room. She would be in nobody’s way, you know, in that part
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the house.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt’s ill-breeding, and made
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: no answer.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drew a chair near her. Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: talked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her, and moving with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: countenance. Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: convenient pause turned to him with an arch smile, and said,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me. But I will not be alarmed, though your sister _does_ play so well.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: There is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the will of others. My courage always rises with every attempt to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: intimidate me.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I shall not say that you are mistaken,” he replied, “because you could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: have had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know, that you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which, in fact,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: are not your own.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in meeting with a person so well able to expose my real character, in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: part of the world where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of credit. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire--and, give me
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: leave to say, very impolitic too--for it is provoking me to retaliate,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and such things may come out as will shock your relations to hear.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am not afraid of you,” said he, smilingly.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,” cried Colonel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Fitzwilliam. “I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You shall hear, then--but prepare for something very dreadful. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know, was at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a ball--and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced only four
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dances! I am sorry to pain you, but so it was. He danced only four
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain knowledge, more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner. Mr. Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you cannot deny the fact.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: beyond my own party.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room. Well, Colonel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Fitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Perhaps,” said Darcy, “I should have judged better had I sought an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: introduction, but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: education, and who has lived in the world, is ill-qualified to recommend
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself to strangers?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I can answer your question,” said Fitzwilliam, “without applying to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: concerns, as I often see done.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: masterly manner which I see so many women’s do. They have not the same
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: have always supposed it to be my own fault--because I would not take
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as capable as any other woman’s of superior execution.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right. You have employed your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: time much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: think anything wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what they were talking of. Elizabeth immediately began playing again.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: when the door opened, and to her very great surprise Mr. Darcy, and Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be within.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seemed in danger of sinking into total silence. It was absolutely
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: departure, she observed,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Perfectly so, I thank you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She found that she was to receive no other answer; and, after a short
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pause, added,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: returning to Netherfield again?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very little of his time there in future. He has many friends, and he is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: increasing.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for the
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: principle.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: He took the hint and soon began with, “This seems a very comfortable
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I believe she did--and I am sure she could not have bestowed her
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Mr. Collins appears very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however; and, in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: journey. Yes, I call it a very easy distance.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the match,” cried Elizabeth. “I should never have said Mrs. Collins
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was settled _near_ her family.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Anything beyond
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As he spoke there was a sort of smile, which Elizabeth fancied she
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Netherfield, and she blushed as she answered,--

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the present distance.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been always at Longbourn.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being with him, as well as by his evident admiration, of her former
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam’s manners, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: believed he might have the best informed mind.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But why Mr. Darcy came so often to the Parsonage it was more difficult
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to understand. It could not be for society, as he frequently sat there
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ten minutes together without opening his lips; and when he did speak, it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice--a sacrifice to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: propriety, not a pleasure to himself. He seldom appeared really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: animated. Mrs. Collins knew not what to make of him. Colonel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Fitzwilliam’s occasionally laughing at his stupidity proved that he was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: generally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her; and as she would have liked to believe this change the effect of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seriously to work to find it out: she watched him whenever they were at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: certainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: look was disputable. It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seemed nothing but absence of mind.

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: vanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Colonel Fitzwilliam. He was, beyond comparison, the pleasantest man: he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.

text: More than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy. She felt all the perverseness of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought; and, to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him, at first,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that it was a favourite haunt of hers. How it could occur a second time,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: therefore, was very odd! Yet it did, and even the third. It seemed like
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance; for on these occasions it was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: never said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rencounter that he was asking some odd unconnected questions--about her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins’s happiness; and that in speaking of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Rosings, and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: expect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _there_ too. His words seemed to imply it. Could he have Colonel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Fitzwilliam in his thoughts? She supposed, if he meant anything, he must
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter. It distressed her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pales opposite the Parsonage.

text: She was engaged one day, as she walked, in re-perusing Jane’s last
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: letter, and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: written in spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she saw, on looking up, that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Putting away the letter immediately, and forcing a smile, she said,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I did not know before that you ever walked this way.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have been making the tour of the park,” he replied, “as I generally
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: do every year, and intended to close it with a call at the Parsonage.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Are you going much farther?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “No, I should have turned in a moment.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: And accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: together.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes--if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arranges the business just as he pleases.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: great pleasure in the power of choice. I do not know anybody who seems
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: more to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “He likes to have his own way very well,” replied Colonel Fitzwilliam.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dependence.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “In my opinion, the younger son of an earl can know very little of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: either. Now, seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wherever you chose or procuring anything you had a fancy for?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “These are home questions--and perhaps I cannot say that I have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: experienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: weight, I may suffer from the want of money. Younger sons cannot marry
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: where they like.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: do.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Our habits of expense make us too dependent, and there are not many in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: money.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would be an unpleasant thing.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice
