text: When they were gone, Elizabeth, as if intending to exasperate herself as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much as possible against Mr. Darcy, chose for her employment the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: examination of all the letters which Jane had written to her since her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being in Kent. They contained no actual complaint, nor was there any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: revival of past occurrences, or any communication of present suffering.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cheerfulness which had been used to characterize her style, and which,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself, and kindly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded. Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal. Mr. Darcy’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict gave her a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: keener sense of her sister’s sufferings. It was some consolation to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the next,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and a still greater that in less than a fortnight she should herself be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with Jane again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: spirits, by all that affection could do.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She could not think of Darcy’s leaving Kent without remembering that his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cousin was to go with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that he had no intentions at all, and, agreeable as he was, she did not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mean to be unhappy about him.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: door-bell; and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her. But
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: affected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: room. In a hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She answered him with cold civility. He sat down for a few moments, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: then getting up walked about the room. Elizabeth was surprised, but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: said not a word. After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in an agitated manner, and thus began:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s astonishment was beyond expression. She stared, coloured,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doubted, and was silent. This he considered sufficient encouragement,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and the avowal of all that he felt and had long felt for her immediately
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: followed. He spoke well; but there were feelings besides those of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: heart to be detailed, and he was not more eloquent on the subject of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: tenderness than of pride. His sense of her inferiority, of its being a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: degradation, of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suit.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In spite of her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not be insensible to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the compliment of such a man’s affection, and though her intentions did
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.

text: He even looked at her with a smile of affected incredulity.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Can you deny that you have done it?” she repeated.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: kinder than towards myself.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection,

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But it is not merely this affair,” she continued, “on which my dislike
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: decided. Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: many months ago from Mr. Wickham. On this subject, what can you have to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: say? In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or under what misrepresentation can you here impose upon others?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.

text: “Who that knows what his misfortunes have been can help feeling an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: interest in him?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: misfortunes have been great indeed.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reduced him to his present state of poverty--comparative poverty. You
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: independence which was no less his due than his desert. You have done
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all this! and yet you can treat the mention of his misfortunes with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: contempt and ridicule.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: more gentlemanlike manner.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She saw him start at this; but he said nothing, and she continued,--

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the gates into the ground.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which edged the park: he was moving that way; and fearful of its being
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Be not alarmed, madam, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its containing any repetition of those sentiments, or renewal of those
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: offers, which were last night so disgusting to you. I write without any
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which, for the happiness of both, cannot be too soon forgotten; and the
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and read. You must, therefore, pardon the freedom with which I demand
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: demand it of your justice.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Two offences of a very different nature, and by no means of equal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: magnitude, you last night laid to my charge. The first mentioned was,
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prosperity and blasted the prospects of Mr. Wickham. Wilfully and
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its exertion, would be a depravity, to which the separation of two young
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: persons whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks, could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: bear no comparison. But from the severity of that blame which was last
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be in future secured, when the following account of my actions and
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be obeyed, and further apology would be absurd. I had not been long in
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: preferred your elder sister to any other young woman in the country. But
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was not till the evening of the dance at Netherfield that I had any
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in love before. At that ball, while I had the honour of dancing with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir William Lucas’s accidental
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: information, that Bingley’s attentions to your sister had given rise to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a general expectation of their marriage. He spoke of it as a certain
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: event, of which the time alone could be undecided. From that moment I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: observed my friend’s behaviour attentively; and I could then perceive
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that his partiality for Miss Bennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in him. Your sister I also watched. Her look and manners were open,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cheerful, and engaging as ever, but without any symptom of peculiar
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regard; and I remained convinced, from the evening’s scrutiny, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though she received his attentions with pleasure, she did not invite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them by any participation of sentiment. If _you_ have not been mistaken
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: here, _I_ must have been in an error. Your superior knowledge of your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister must make the latter probable. If it be so, if I have been misled
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: by such error to inflict pain on her, your resentment has not been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unreasonable. But I shall not scruple to assert, that the serenity of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: your sister’s countenance and air was such as might have given the most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acute observer a conviction that, however amiable her temper, her heart
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was not likely to be easily touched. That I was desirous of believing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her indifferent is certain; but I will venture to say that my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: investigations and decisions are not usually influenced by my hopes or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fears. I did not believe her to be indifferent because I wished it; I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: believed it on impartial conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: My objections to the marriage were not merely those which I last night
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in my own case; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my friend as to me. But there were other causes of repugnance; causes

text: which, though still existing, and existing to an equal degree in both
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: instances, I had myself endeavoured to forget, because they were not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: immediately before me. These causes must be stated, though briefly. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: situation of your mother’s family, though objectionable, was nothing in
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that he had deceived himself was no very difficult point. To persuade
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: affair, on which I do not reflect with satisfaction; it is that I
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: done, however, and it was done for the best. On this subject I have
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was then but fifteen, which must be her excuse; and after stating her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed the knowledge of it to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself. I joined them unexpectedly a day or two before the intended
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: elopement; and then Georgiana, unable to support the idea of grieving
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as a father,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acknowledged the whole to me. You may imagine what I felt and how I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acted. Regard for my sister’s credit and feelings prevented any public
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place immediately,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and Mrs. Younge was of course removed from her charge. Mr. Wickham’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: chief object was unquestionably my sister’s fortune, which is thirty
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of revenging
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself on me was a strong inducement. His revenge would have been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: complete indeed. This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which we have been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reject it as false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: towards Mr. Wickham. I know not in what manner, under what form of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: falsehood, he has imposed on you; but his success is not perhaps to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wondered at, ignorant as you previously were of everything concerning
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: either. Detection could not be in your power, and suspicion certainly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not in your inclination. You may possibly wonder why all this was not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: told you last night. But I was not then master enough of myself to know
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what could or ought to be revealed. For the truth of everything here
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: related, I can appeal more particularly to the testimony of Colonel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Fitzwilliam, who, from our near relationship and constant intimacy, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: still more as one of the executors of my father’s will, has been
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cannot be prevented by the same cause from confiding in my cousin; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: course of the morning. I will only add, God bless you.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “FITZWILLIAM DARCY.”

text: Elizabeth, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its contents. But such as they were, it may be well supposed how eagerly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Her feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined. With amazement did
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal. With a strong
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what had happened at Netherfield. She read with an eagerness which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hardly left her power of comprehension; and from impatience of knowing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what the next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sense of the one before her eyes. His belief of her sister’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: insensibility she instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: real, the worst objections to the match, made her too angry to have any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wish of doing him justice. He expressed no regret for what he had done
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which satisfied her; his style was not penitent, but haughty. It was all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pride and insolence.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham--when
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself--her feelings
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her. She wished
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: This cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!”--and when she had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regard it, that she would never look in it again.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing, she walked on; but it would not do: in half a minute the letter
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was unfolded again; and collecting herself as well as she could, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: own words. So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the will, the difference was great. What Wickham had said of the living
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was fresh in her memory; and as she recalled his very words, it was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other, and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not err. But when she read and re-read, with the closest attention, the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: particulars immediately following of Wickham’s resigning all pretensions
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate. She put down the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impartiality--deliberated on the probability of each statement--but with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little success. On both sides it was only assertion. Again she read on.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: render Mr. Darcy’s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Wickham’s charge exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: bring no proof of its injustice. She had never heard of him before his
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wondered it had escaped her before. She saw the indelicacy of putting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with his conduct. She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of seeing Mr. Darcy--that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _he_ should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself; but that after their removal, it had been everywhere discussed;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: character, though he had assured her that respect for the father would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always prevent his exposing the son.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: How differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned! His
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: His behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive: he had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: either been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: incautiously shown. Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and fainter; and in further justification of Mr. Darcy, she could not
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could she think, without feeling that she had been blind, partial,
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “How despicably have I acted!” she cried. “I, who have prided myself on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: my discernment! I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: vanity in useless or blameless distrust. How humiliating is this
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: concerned. Till this moment, I never knew myself.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been in waiting near the lodges, to make them his parting obeisance, was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: able to bring home the pleasing intelligence of their appearing in very
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Ladyship’s indignation would have been. “What would she have said? how

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The first week of their return was soon gone. The second began. It was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the last of the regiment’s stay in Meryton, and all the young ladies in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the neighbourhood were drooping apace. The dejection was almost
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: universal. The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat, drink,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and sleep, and pursue the usual course of their employments. Very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: frequently were they reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia, whose own misery was extreme, and who could not comprehend such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hard-heartedness in any of the family.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Good Heaven! What is to become of us? What are we to do?” would they
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: often exclaim in the bitterness of woe. “How can you be smiling so,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lizzy?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Their affectionate mother shared all their grief; she remembered what
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she had herself endured on a similar occasion five-and-twenty years ago.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am sure,” said she, “I cried for two days together when Colonel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miller’s regiment went away. I thought I should have broke my heart.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am sure I shall break _mine_,” said Lydia.

text: “If one could but go to Brighton!” observed Mrs. Bennet.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh yes!--if one could but go to Brighton! But papa is so disagreeable.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “A little sea-bathing would set me up for ever.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: added Kitty.

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Longbourn House. Elizabeth tried to be diverted by them; but all sense
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of pleasure was lost in shame. She felt anew the justice of Mr. Darcy’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: objections; and never had she before been so much disposed to pardon his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: interference in the views of his friend.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But the gloom of Lydia’s prospect was shortly cleared away; for she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the colonel of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regiment, to accompany her to Brighton. This invaluable friend was a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: very young woman, and very lately married. A resemblance in good-humour
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and good spirits had recommended her and Lydia to each other, and out of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their _three_ months’ acquaintance they had been intimate _two_.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The rapture of Lydia on this occasion, her adoration of Mrs. Forster,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the delight of Mrs. Bennet, and the mortification of Kitty, are scarcely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be described. Wholly inattentive to her sister’s feelings, Lydia flew
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: about the house in restless ecstasy, calling for everyone’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: congratulations, and laughing and talking with more violence than ever;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repining at her fate
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in terms as unreasonable as her accent was peevish.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I cannot see why Mrs. Forster should not ask _me_ as well as Lydia,”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: circumstances.”

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: weeks at Rosings, and asked him if he were acquainted with the former.

text: He looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but, with a moment’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: recollection, and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: asked her how she had liked him. Her answer was warmly in his favour.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: With an air of indifference, he soon afterwards added, “How long did you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: say that he was at Rosings?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Nearly three weeks.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And you saw him frequently?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, almost every day.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “His manners are very different from his cousin’s.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, very different; but I think Mr. Darcy improves on acquaintance.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Indeed!” cried Wickham, with a look which did not escape her. “And pray
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: may I ask--” but checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is it in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: address that he improves? Has he deigned to add aught of civility to his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ordinary style? for I dare not hope,” he continued, in a lower and more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: serious tone, “that he is improved in essentials.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Oh, no!” said Elizabeth. “In essentials, I believe, he is very much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what he ever was.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: While she spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rejoice over her words or to distrust their meaning. There was a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: something in her countenance which made him listen with an apprehensive
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and anxious attention, while she added,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “When I said that he improved on acquaintance, I did not mean that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: either his mind or manners were in a state of improvement; but that,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from knowing him better, his disposition was better understood.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham’s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: look; for a few minutes he was silent; till, shaking off his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: embarrassment, he turned to her again, and said in the gentlest of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accents,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You, who so well know my feelings towards Mr. Darcy, will readily
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: comprehend how sincerely I must rejoice that he is wise enough to assume
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: even the _appearance_ of what is right. His pride, in that direction,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: may be of service, if not to himself, to many others, for it must deter
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him from such foul misconduct as I have suffered by. I only fear that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been alluding, is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: merely adopted on his visits to his aunt, of whose good opinion and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: judgment he stands much in awe. His fear of her has always operated, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be imputed to his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wish of forwarding the match with Miss de Bourgh, which I am certain he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: has very much at heart.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this, but she answered only by a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: slight inclination of the head. She saw that he wanted to engage her on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the old subject of his grievances, and she was in no humour to indulge
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him. The rest of the evening passed with the _appearance_, on his side,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mutual desire of never meeting again.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When the party broke up, Lydia returned with Mrs. Forster to Meryton,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from whence they were to set out early the next morning. The separation
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: between her and her family was rather noisy than pathetic. Kitty was the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only one who shed tears; but she did weep from vexation and envy. Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet was diffuse in her good wishes for the felicity of her daughter,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and impressive in her injunctions that she would not miss the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: opportunity of enjoying herself as much as possible,--advice which there
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was every reason to believe would be attended to; and, in the clamorous
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell, the more gentle adieus
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her sisters were uttered without being heard.

text: CHAPTER XLII.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Had Elizabeth’s opinion been all drawn from her own family, she could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not have formed a very pleasing picture of conjugal felicity or domestic
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: comfort. Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of good-humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their marriage put an end to all real affection for her. Respect,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: esteem, and confidence had vanished for ever; and all his views of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: domestic happiness were overthrown. But Mr. Bennet was not of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which his own
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: imprudence had brought on in any of those pleasures which too often
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: console the unfortunate for their folly or their vice. He was fond of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the country and of books; and from these tastes had arisen his principal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enjoyments. To his wife he was very little otherwise indebted than as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement. This is not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wife; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: father’s behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: children, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from so ill-judged a direction of talents--talents which, rightly used,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When Elizabeth had rejoiced over Wickham’s departure, she found little
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment. Their parties
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: abroad were less varied than before; and at home she had a mother and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister, whose constant repinings at the dulness of everything around
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kitty
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: might in time regain her natural degree of sense, since the disturbers
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her brain were removed, her other sister, from whose disposition
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: folly and assurance, by a situation of such double danger as a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: watering-place and a camp. Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: has been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had looked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: forward with impatient desire, did not, in taking place, bring all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: satisfaction she had promised herself. It was consequently necessary to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity; to have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some other point on which her wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console herself for the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: present, and prepare for another disappointment. Her tour to the Lakes
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was now the object of her happiest thoughts: it was her best consolation
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of her mother
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and Kitty made inevitable; and could she have included Jane in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: scheme, every part of it would have been perfect.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But it is fortunate,” thought she, “that I have something to wish for.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Were the whole arrangement complete, my disappointment would be certain.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister’s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasure realized. A scheme of which every part promises delight can
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: never be successful; and general disappointment is only warded off by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the defence of some little peculiar vexation.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When Lydia went away she promised to write very often and very minutely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always long expected, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always very short. Those to her mother contained little else than that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they were just returned from the library, where such and such officers
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had attended them, and where she had seen such beautiful ornaments as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: made her quite wild; that she had a new gown, or a new parasol, which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: violent hurry, as Mrs. Forster called her, and they were going to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: camp; and from her correspondence with her sister there was still less
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be learnt, for her letters to Kitty, though rather longer, were much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: too full of lines under the words to be made public.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: After the first fortnight or three weeks of her absence, health,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-humour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn. Everything
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wore a happier aspect. The families who had been in town for the winter
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: came back again, and summer finery and summer engagements arose. Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet was restored to her usual querulous serenity; and by the middle
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of June Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: without tears,--an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hope, that by the following Christmas she might be so tolerably
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day, unless, by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office, another regiment
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should be quartered in Meryton.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: approaching; and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arrived from Mrs. Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: curtailed its extent. Mr. Gardiner would be prevented by business from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: setting out till a fortnight later in July, and must be in London again
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: within a month; and as that left too short a period for them to go so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: far, and see so much as they had proposed, or at least to see it with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the leisure and comfort they had built on, they were obliged to give up
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the Lakes, and substitute a more contracted tour; and, according to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: present plan, were to go no farther northward than Derbyshire. In that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: weeks; and to Mrs. Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: town where she had formerly passed some years of her life, and where
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Dovedale, or the Peak.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was excessively disappointed: she had set her heart on seeing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the Lakes; and still thought there might have been time enough. But it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was her business to be satisfied--and certainly her temper to be happy;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and all was soon right again.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: With the mention of Derbyshire, there were many ideas connected. It was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impossible for her to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: owner. “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and rob it of a few petrified spars, without his perceiving me.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The period of expectation was now doubled. Four weeks were to pass away
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before her uncle and aunt’s arrival. But they did pass away, and Mr. and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Longbourn. The children, two girls of six and eight years old, and two
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: younger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their cousin
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sweetness of temper exactly adapted her for attending to them in every
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: way--teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the next
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: morning with Elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement. One
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enjoyment was certain--that of suitableness as companions; a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inconveniences--cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure--and affection
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and intelligence, which might supply it among themselves if there were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disappointments abroad.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: It is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nor of any of the remarkable places through which their route thither
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: lay--Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, etc., are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sufficiently known. A small part of Derbyshire is all the present
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: concern. To the little town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: former residence, and where she had lately learned that some
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance still remained, they bent their steps, after having seen
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all the principal wonders of the country; and within five miles of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lambton, Elizabeth found, from her aunt, that Pemberley was situated. It
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was not in their direct road; nor more than a mile or two out of it. In
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: talking over their route the evening before, Mrs. Gardiner expressed an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inclination to see the place again. Mr. Gardiner declared his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: willingness, and Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My love, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much?” said her aunt. “A place, too, with which so many of your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance are connected. Wickham passed all his youth there, you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: know.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was distressed. She felt that she had no business at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Pemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it. She
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must own that she was tired of great houses: after going over so many,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Gardiner abused her stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: richly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: grounds are delightful. They have some of the finest woods in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: country.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth said no more; but her mind could not acquiesce. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: possibility of meeting Mr. Darcy, while viewing the place, instantly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: occurred. It would be dreadful! She blushed at the very idea; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thought it would be better to speak openly to her aunt, than to run such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a risk. But against this there were objections; and she finally resolved
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that it could be the last resource, if her private inquiries as to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: absence of the family were unfavourably answered.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the summer? A most welcome negative followed the last question; and her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: alarms being now removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to the scheme.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: To Pemberley, therefore, they were to go.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: CHAPTER XLIII.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The park was very large, and contained great variety of ground. They
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: entered it in one of its lowest points, and drove for some time through
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: every remarkable spot and point of view. They gradually ascended for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: half a mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: eminence, where the wood ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of the valley, into which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the road with some abruptness wound. It was a large, handsome stone
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: building, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of high
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: woody hills; and in front a stream of some natural importance was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: swelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance. Its banks
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were neither formal nor falsely adorned. Elizabeth was delighted. She
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste. They were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be mistress of Pemberley might be something!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: meeting its owner returned. She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mistaken. On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wonder at her being where she was.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The housekeeper came; a respectable looking elderly woman, much less
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her. They
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: followed her into the dining-parlour. It was a large, well-proportioned
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: room, handsomely fitted up. Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to a window to enjoy its prospect. The hill, crowned with wood, from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which they had descended, receiving increased abruptness from the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: distance, was a beautiful object. Every disposition of the ground was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good; and she looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on its banks, and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it, with delight. As they passed into other rooms, these objects were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: taking different positions; but from every window there were beauties
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to be seen. The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suitable to the fortune of their proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: admiration of his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fine,--with less of splendour, and more real elegance, than the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: furniture of Rosings.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress! With
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: these rooms I might have now been familiarly acquainted! Instead of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt. But, no,” recollecting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself, “that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: This was a lucky recollection--it saved her from something like regret.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether her master were really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: absent, but had not courage for it. At length, however, the question was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while Mrs. Reynolds
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: replied, that he was; adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with a large
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own journey had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not by any circumstance been delayed a day!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Her aunt now called her to look at a picture. She approached, and saw
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the likeness of Mr. Wickham, suspended, amongst several other
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: miniatures, over the mantel-piece. Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she liked it. The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: picture of a young gentleman, the son of her late master’s steward, who
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had been brought up by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: army,” she added; “but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: return it.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “is my master--and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other--about eight years ago.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have heard much of your master’s fine person,” said Mrs. Gardiner,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looking at the picture; “it is a handsome face. But, Lizzy, you can tell
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: us whether it is like or not.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Reynolds’ respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase on this
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: intimation of her knowing her master.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth coloured, and said, “A little.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, ma’am?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, very handsome.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am sure _I_ know none so handsome; but in the gallery upstairs you
