text: aunt; “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: say with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _I_ have seen nothing of it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “To be sure, Lizzy,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as Wickham;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or rather he has not Wickham’s countenance, for his features are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: perfectly good. But how came you to tell us that he was so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disagreeable?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could: said that she had liked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him better when they met in Kent than before, and that she had never
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seen him so pleasant as this morning.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at his word about fishing, as he might change his mind another day, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: warn me off his grounds.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “From what we have seen of him,” continued Mrs. Gardiner, “I really
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anybody as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured look.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance, that would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But, to be sure, the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good lady who showed us the house did give him a most flaming character!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a liberal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: master, I suppose, and _that_, in the eye of a servant, comprehends
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: every virtue.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his behaviour to Wickham; and, therefore, gave them to understand, in as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire. In
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk, they had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy’s civility, and, above
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: CHAPTER XLIV.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was, consequently,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their own
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arrival at Lambton these visitors came. They had been walking about the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: place with some of their new friends, and were just returned to the inn
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and lady in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: curricle driving up the street. Elizabeth, immediately recognizing the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of surprise
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to her relations, by acquainting them with the honour which she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: expected. Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the business. Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they now felt
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a quarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece. While these
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s feelings was every moment increasing. She was quite amazed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at her own discomposure; but, amongst other causes of disquiet, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: suspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: up and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: took place. With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself. Since her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only exceedingly shy. She found it difficult to obtain even a word from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her beyond a monosyllable.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: womanly and graceful. She was less handsome than her brother, but there
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was sense and good-humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unassuming and gentle. Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: relieved by discerning such different feelings.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They had not been long together before Darcy told her that Bingley was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley’s quick step
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room. All
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth’s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inquired in a friendly, though general, way, after her family, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looked and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: To Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than to herself. They had long wished to see him. The whole party before
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them, indeed, excited a lively attention. The suspicions which had just
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arisen of Mr. Darcy and their niece, directed their observation towards
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: each with an earnest, though guarded, inquiry; and they soon drew from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew what
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was to love. Of the lady’s sensations they remained a little in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: evident enough.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do. She wanted to ascertain the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feelings of each of her visitors, she wanted to compose her own, and to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she endeavoured to give pleasure were pre-possessed in her favour.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley was ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleased.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “To make herself agreeable to all”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and oh!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: like manner. Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: former occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance. But,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: behaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane. No
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard. Nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: occurred between them that could justify the hopes of his sister. On
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this point she was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: occurred ere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a recollection of Jane, not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: saying more that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared. He
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: observed to her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in a tone which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: time since he had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reply, he added, “It is above eight months. We have not met since the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: 26th of November, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: took occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _all_ her sisters were at Longbourn. There was not much in the question,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nor in the preceding remark; but there was a look and a manner which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gave them meaning.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: It was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself; but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whenever she did catch a glimpse she saw an expression of general
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: complaisance, and in all that he said, she heard an accent so far
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: removed from _hauteur_ or disdain of his companions, as convinced her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: however temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: day. When she saw him thus seeking the acquaintance, and courting the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: have been a disgrace; when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but to the very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage, the difference, the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: change was so great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hardly restrain her astonishment from being visible. Never, even in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: company of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed, would draw
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Rosings.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Their visitors stayed with them above half an hour; and when they arose
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: at Pemberley, before they left the country. Miss Darcy, though with a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: diffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: readily obeyed. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: how _she_, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: acceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head. Presuming, however,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: again, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: make after all their Hertfordshire friends. Elizabeth, construing all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on this account, as well as some others, found herself, when their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visitors left them, capable of considering the last half hour with some
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: satisfaction, though while it was passing the enjoyment of it had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: little. Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner’s curiosity; it was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not their wish to force her communication. It was evident that she was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was evident that he was very much in love with her. They saw much to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: interest, but nothing to justify inquiry.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Of Mr. Darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well; and, as far
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as their acquaintance reached, there was no fault to find. They could
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not be untouched by his politeness; and had they drawn his character
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from their own feelings and his servant’s report, without any reference
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to any other account, the circle in Hertfordshire to which he was known
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would not have recognized it for Mr. Darcy. There was now an interest,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: however, in believing the housekeeper; and they soon became sensible
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that the authority of a servant, who had known him since he was four
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: years old, and whose own manners indicated respectability, was not to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hastily rejected. Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight. They had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nothing to accuse him of but pride; pride he probably had, and if not,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market town
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: where the family did not visit. It was acknowledged, however, that he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was a liberal man, and did much good among the poor.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: With respect to Wickham, the travellers soon found that he was not held
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there in much estimation; for though the chief of his concerns with the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: son of his patron were imperfectly understood, it was yet a well-known
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fact that, on his quitting Derbyshire, he had left many debts behind
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him, which Mr. Darcy afterwards discharged.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: long enough to determine her feelings towards _one_ in that mansion; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she lay awake two whole hours, endeavouring to make them out. She
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: certainly did not hate him. No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that could be so called. The respect created by the conviction of his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: time ceased to be repugnant to her feelings; and it was now heightened
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: into somewhat of a friendlier nature by the testimony so highly in his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which yesterday had produced. But above all, above respect and esteem,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: there was a motive within her of good-will which could not be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: overlooked. It was gratitude;--gratitude, not merely for having once
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: loved her, but for loving her still well enough to forgive all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: petulance and acrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unjust accusations accompanying her rejection. He who, she had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: persuaded, would avoid her as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accidental meeting, most eager to preserve the acquaintance; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: without any indelicate display of regard, or any peculiarity of manner,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: where their two selves only were concerned, was soliciting the good
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: opinion of her friends, and bent on making her known to his sister. Such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a change in a man of so much pride excited not only astonishment but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gratitude--for to love, ardent love, it must be attributed; and, as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: such, its impression on her was of a sort to be encouraged, as by no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: means unpleasing, though it could not be exactly defined. She respected,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she esteemed, she was grateful to him, she felt a real interest in his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: welfare; and she only wanted to know how far she wished that welfare to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: depend upon herself, and how far it would be for the happiness of both
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that she should employ the power, which her fancy told her she still
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: possessed, of bringing on the renewal of his addresses.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: It had been settled in the evening, between the aunt and niece, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: such a striking civility as Miss Darcy’s, in coming to them on the very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: day of her arrival at Pemberley--for she had reached it only to a late
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: breakfast--ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled, by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: morning. They were, therefore, to go. Elizabeth was pleased; though when
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Gardiner left them soon after breakfast. The fishing scheme had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: renewed the day before, and a positive engagement made of his meeting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some of the gentlemen at Pemberley by noon.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration:
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Engaged by the river”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: CHAPTER XLV.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: [Illustration]
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with how much civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be renewed.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: On reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer. Its windows,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In this room they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: London. Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved. Mrs. Gardiner and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: By Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: succeeded for a few moments. It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: others; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on. Miss Darcy looked as if she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: calling her attention. This observation would not have prevented her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her. She expected every
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine. After
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inquiry after the health of her family. She answered with equal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: matter. It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should form
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friendless, and who was actually staying in his Colonel’s family, that I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: am strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not adequate to the risk.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Upon my word,” said Mrs. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: opinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: interest, for him to be guilty of it. I cannot think so very ill of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham. Can you, yourself, Lizzie, so wholly give him up, as to believe
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him capable of it?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Not perhaps of neglecting his own interest. But of every other neglect
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland, if that had been the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: case?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet had very often wished, before this period of his life, that,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum, for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him. He now wished it more than ever. Had he done his duty in that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: honour or credit could now be purchased for her. The satisfaction of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be her husband might then have rested in its proper place.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law; and he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: When first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: useless; for, of course, they were to have a son. This son was to join
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and younger children would by that means be provided for. Five daughters
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet, for many years after Lydia’s birth, had been certain that he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would. This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then too
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: late to be saving. Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy; and her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: husband’s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: income.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mrs. Bennet and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the children. But in what proportions it should be divided amongst the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: latter depended on the will of the parents. This was one point, with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: regard to Lydia at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him. In
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of his brother, though
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: expressed most concisely, he then delivered on paper his perfect
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: approbation of all that was done, and his willingness to fulfil the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: engagements that had been made for him. He had never before supposed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arrangement. He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser, by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: through her mother’s hands, Lydia’s expenses had been very little within
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that sum.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: That it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: another very welcome surprise; for his chief wish at present was to have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as little trouble in the business as possible. When the first transports
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: naturally returned to all his former indolence. His letter was soon
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: despatched; for though dilatory in undertaking business, he was quick in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: its execution. He begged to know further particulars of what he was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: indebted to his brother; but was too angry with Lydia to send any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: message to her.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The good news quickly spread through the house; and with proportionate
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: speed through the neighbourhood. It was borne in the latter with decent
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: philosophy. To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: conversation, had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: happiest alternative, been secluded from the world in some distant
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: farm-house. But there was much to be talked of, in marrying her; and the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-natured wishes for her well-doing, which had proceeded before from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton, lost but little of their spirit
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in this change of circumstances, because with such a husband her misery
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Their sister’s wedding-day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: probably more than she felt for herself. The carriage was sent to meet
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them at----, and they were to return in it by dinnertime. Their arrival
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets--and Jane more especially, who
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had _she_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must endure.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They came. The family were assembled in the breakfast-room to receive
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them. Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet, as the carriage drove up to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anxious, uneasy.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia’s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she ran into the room. Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand with an affectionate smile to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy, with an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: alacrity which showed no doubt of their happiness.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Their reception from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so cordial. His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: opened his lips. The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enough to provoke him.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet was shocked. Lydia was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy, and fearless. She turned
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: from sister to sister, demanding their congratulations; and when at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: length they all sat down, looked eagerly round the room, took notice of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: some little alteration in it, and observed, with a laugh, that it was a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: great while since she had been there.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself; but his manners
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were always so pleasing, that, had his character and his marriage been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all. Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: down, resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impudence of an impudent man. _She_ blushed, and Jane blushed; but the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cheeks of the two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: colour.

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with a good-humoured ease, which she felt very unable to equal in her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: replies. They seemed each of them to have the happiest memories in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: world. Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the world.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had received his commission before he left London, and he was to join
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: No one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: having very frequent parties at home. These parties were acceptable to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: think than such as did not.
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: find it; not equal to Lydia’s for him. She had scarcely needed her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him. He did
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: everything best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to her letter as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: soon as she possibly could. She was no sooner in possession of it, than
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hurrying into the little copse, where she was least likely to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: interrupted, she sat down on one of the benches, and prepared to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: happy; for the length of the letter convinced her that it did not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: contain a denial.

text: /* RIGHT “Gracechurch Street, _Sept. 6_. */
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My dear Niece,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: morning to answering it, as I foresee that a _little_ writing will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not comprise what I have to tell you. I must confess myself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: surprised by your application; I did not expect it from _you_.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Don’t think me angry, however, for I only mean to let you know,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that I had not imagined such inquiries to be necessary on _your_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: side. If you do not choose to understand me, forgive my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: impertinence. Your uncle is as much surprised as I am; and nothing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but the belief of your being a party concerned would have allowed
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him to act as he has done. But if you are really innocent and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ignorant, I must be more explicit. On the very day of my coming
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most unexpected visitor. Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy called, and was shut up with him several hours. It was all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so dreadfully racked
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as _yours_ seems to have been. He came to tell Mr. Gardiner that he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were, and that he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had seen and talked with them both--Wickham repeatedly, Lydia once.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day after
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them. The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: himself that Wickham’s worthlessness had not been so well known as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: confide in him. He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pride, and confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: lay his private actions open to the world. His character was to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: speak for itself. He called it, therefore, his duty to step
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: forward, and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: by himself. If he _had another_ motive, I am sure it would never
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: disgrace him. He had been some days in town before he was able to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: discover them; but he had something to direct his search, which was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: more than _we_ had; and the consciousness of this was another
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reason for his resolving to follow us. There is a lady, it seems, a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago governess to Miss Darcy, and was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dismissed from her charge on some cause of disapprobation, though
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he did not say what. She then took a large house in Edward Street,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and has since maintained herself by letting lodgings. This Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with Wickham; and he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: went to her for intelligence of him, as soon as he got to town. But
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was two or three days before he could get from her what he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wanted. She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and corruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: found. Wickham, indeed, had gone to her on their first arrival in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: London; and had she been able to receive them into her house, they
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would have taken up their abode with her. At length, however, our
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: kind friend procured the wished-for direction. They were in ----
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Street. He saw Wickham, and afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: His first object with her, he acknowledged, had been to persuade
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her to quit her present disgraceful situation, and return to her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friends as soon as they could be prevailed on to receive her,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: offering his assistance as far as it would go. But he found Lydia
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: absolutely resolved on remaining where she was. She cared for none
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: leaving Wickham. She was sure they should be married some time or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other, and it did not much signify when. Since such were her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feelings, it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marriage, which, in his very first conversation with Wickham, he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: easily learnt had never been _his_ design. He confessed himself
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: obliged to leave the regiment on account of some debts of honour
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which were very pressing; and scrupled not to lay all the ill
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: consequences of Lydia’s flight on her own folly alone. He meant to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resign his commission immediately; and as to his future situation,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he could conjecture very little about it. He must go somewhere, but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he did not know where, and he knew he should have nothing to live
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on. Mr. Darcy asked why he did not marry your sister at once.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Though Mr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: been able to do something for him, and his situation must have been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: benefited by marriage. But he found, in reply to this question,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that Wickham still cherished the hope of more effectually making
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his fortune by marriage, in some other country. Under such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: circumstances, however, he was not likely to be proof against the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: temptation of immediate relief. They met several times, for there
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was much to be discussed. Wickham, of course, wanted more than he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: could get; but at length was reduced to be reasonable. Everything
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being settled between _them_, Mr. Darcy’s next step was to make
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Street the evening before I came home. But Mr. Gardiner could not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be seen; and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was still with him, but would quit town the next morning. He did
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not judge your father to be a person whom he could so properly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: consult as your uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: till after the departure of the former. He did not leave his name,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and till the next day it was only known that a gentleman had called
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on business. On Saturday he came again. Your father was gone, your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: uncle at home, and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: together. They met again on Sunday, and then _I_ saw him too. It
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was not all settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was sent off to Longbourn. But our visitor was very obstinate. I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fancy, Lizzy, that obstinacy is the real defect of his character,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: after all. He has been accused of many faults at different times;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but _this_ is the true one. Nothing was to be done that he did not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: do himself; though I am sure (and I do not speak it to be thanked,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: therefore say nothing about it) your uncle would most readily have
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: settled the whole. They battled it together for a long time, which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was more than either the gentleman or lady concerned in it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: deserved. But at last your uncle was forced to yield, and instead
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of being allowed to be of use to his niece, was forced to put up
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with only having the probable credit of it, which went sorely
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: against the grain; and I really believe your letter this morning
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was due. But, Lizzy, this must go no further than yourself, or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane at most. You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for the young people. His debts are to be paid, amounting, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: believe, to considerably more than a thousand pounds, another
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thousand in addition to her own settled upon _her_, and his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: commission purchased. The reason why all this was to be done by him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: alone, was such as I have given above. It was owing to him, to his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reserve and want of proper consideration, that Wickham’s character
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: received and noticed as he was. Perhaps there was some truth in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _this_; though I doubt whether _his_ reserve, or _anybody’s_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reserve can be answerable for the event. But in spite of all this
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: fine talking, my dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: your uncle would never have yielded, if we had not given him credit
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for _another interest_ in the affair. When all this was resolved
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: It is a relation which you tell me is to give you great surprise; I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hope at least it will not afford you any displeasure. Lydia came to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: us, and Wickham had constant admission to the house. _He_ was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exactly what he had been when I knew him in Hertfordshire; but I
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dined with us the next day, and was to leave town again on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wednesday or Thursday. Will you be very angry with me, my dear
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: enough to say before) how much I like him? His behaviour to us has,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: His understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a little more liveliness, and _that_, if he marry _prudently_, his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wife may teach him. I thought him very sly; he hardly ever
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mentioned your name. But slyness seems the fashion. Pray forgive
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me, if I have been very presuming, or at least do not punish me so
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “M. GARDINER.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: greatest share. The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: produced, of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister’s match--which she had feared to encourage, as an exertion of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: goodness too great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: just, from the pain of obligation--were proved beyond their greatest
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: extent to be true! He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: on himself all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: research; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom he
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: must abominate and despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: meet, reason with, persuade, and finally bribe the man whom he always
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: most wished to avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pronounce. He had done all this for a girl whom he could neither regard
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nor esteem. Her heart did whisper that he had done it for her. But it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was a hope shortly checked by other considerations; and she soon felt
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that even her vanity was insufficient, when required to depend on his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: affection for her, for a woman who had already refused him, as able to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham. Brother-in-law of Wickham! Every kind of pride must revolt from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the connection. He had, to be sure, done much. She was ashamed to think
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: how much. But he had given a reason for his interference, which asked no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: extraordinary stretch of belief. It was reasonable that he should feel
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he had been wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it; and though she would not place herself as his principal inducement,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she could perhaps believe, that remaining partiality for her might
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assist his endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: materially concerned. It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they were under obligations to a person who could never receive a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: return. They owed the restoration of Lydia, her character, everything to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him. Oh, how heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had ever encouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: him! For herself she was humbled; but she was proud of him,--proud that
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: secret. Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Philips, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: neighbours in Meryton.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: world; though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.

text: One morning, about a week after Bingley’s engagement with Jane had been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window by the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: lawn. It was too early in the morning for visitors; and besides, the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours. The horses
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: preceded it, were familiar to them. As it was certain, however, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shrubbery. They both set off; and the conjectures of the remaining three
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: open, and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: They were of course all intending to be surprised: but their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inferior to what Elizabeth felt.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other reply to Elizabeth’s salutation than a slight inclination of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: head, and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: name to her mother on her Ladyship’s entrance, though no request of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: introduction had been made.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: high importance, received her with the utmost politeness. After sitting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for a moment in silence, she said, very stiffly, to Elizabeth,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady, I suppose, is your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mother?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And _that_, I suppose, is one of your sisters?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to a Lady Catherine.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all is lately married,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and my eldest is somewhere about the ground, walking with a young man,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: who, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine, after a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: short silence.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my Lady, I dare say; but, I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assure you, it is much larger than Sir William Lucas’s.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “This must be a most inconvenient sitting-room for the evening in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: summer: the windows are full west.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner; and then
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: added,--

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: will favour me with your company.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: different walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attended her noble guest downstairs. As they passed through the hall,
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: manner:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: journey hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: come.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Indeed, you are mistaken, madam; I have not been at all able to account
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for the honour of seeing you here.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Bennet,” replied her Ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: know that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere _you_ may
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: choose to be, you shall not find _me_ so. My character has ever been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: celebrated for its sincerity and frankness; and in a cause of such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: alarming nature reached me two days ago. I was told, that not only your
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _you_--that Miss Elizabeth Bennet would, in all likelihood, be soon
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: afterwards united to my nephew--my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _know_ it must be a scandalous falsehood, though I would not injure him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so far. What could your Ladyship propose by it?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it--if, indeed, such a report
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: is in existence.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If! do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: industriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: report is spread abroad?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I never heard that it was.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And can you likewise declare, that there is no _foundation_ for it?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your Ladyship. _You_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: may ask questions which _I_ shall not choose to answer.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “This is not to be borne. Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied. Has
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Your Ladyship has declared it to be impossible.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reason. But _your_ arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: have made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family. You
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: may have drawn him in.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I have not been accustomed to such
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: language as this. I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “But you are not entitled to know _mine_; nor will such behaviour as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: this ever induce me to be explicit.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Let me be rightly understood. This match, to which you have the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: presumption to aspire, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: engaged to _my daughter_. Now, what have you to say?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Only this,--that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: make an offer to me.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied,--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind. From their infancy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: they have been intended for each other. It was the favourite wish of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _his_ mother, as well as of hers. While in their cradles we planned the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: union; and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accomplished, is their marriage to be prevented by a young woman of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the family? Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends--to his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: tacit engagement with Miss de Bourgh? Are you lost to every feeling of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: propriety and delicacy? Have you not heard me say, that from his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: earliest hours he was destined for his cousin?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yes; and I had heard it before. But what is that to me? If there is no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: kept from it by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to marry
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss de Bourgh. You both did as much as you could in planning the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marriage. Its completion depended on others. If Mr. Darcy is neither by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: another choice? And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Because honour, decorum, prudence--nay, interest--forbid it. Yes, Miss
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all. You will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be censured, slighted, and despised, by everyone connected with him.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: by any of us.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth. “But the wife of Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to repine.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Obstinate, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this your gratitude
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for my attentions to you last spring? Is nothing due to me on that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: score? Let us sit down. You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be dissuaded from it. I have not been used to submit to any person’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whims. I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “_That_ will make your Ladyship’s situation at present more pitiable;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: but it will have no effect on _me_.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I will not be interrupted! Hear me in silence. My daughter and my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: nephew are formed for each other. They are descended, on the maternal
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: side, from the same noble line; and, on the father’s, from respectable,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: honourable, and ancient, though untitled, families. Their fortune on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: both sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the voice of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them?--the upstart pretensions of a young woman without family,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: connections, or fortune! Is this to be endured? But it must not, shall
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not be! If you were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: quit the sphere in which you have been brought up.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sphere. He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman’s daughter; so far we are
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: equal.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “True. You _are_ a gentleman’s daughter. But what was your mother? Who
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: are your uncles and aunts? Do not imagine me ignorant of their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: condition.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Whatever my connections may be,” said Elizabeth, “if your nephew does
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Tell me, once for all, are you engaged to him?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice
