text: “I am not.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And will you promise me never to enter into such an engagement?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I will make no promise of the kind.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Miss Bennet, I am shocked and astonished. I expected to find a more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into a belief that I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: will ever recede. I shall not go away till you have given me the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: assurance I require.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And I certainly _never_ shall give it. I am not to be intimidated into
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: anything so wholly unreasonable. Your Ladyship wants Mr. Darcy to marry
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: your daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _their_ marriage at all more probable? Supposing him to be attached to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: me, would _my_ refusing to accept his hand make him wish to bestow it on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his cousin? Allow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: frivolous as the application was ill-judged. You have widely mistaken my
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: character, if you think I can be worked on by such persuasions as these.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: How far your nephew might approve of your interference in _his_ affairs,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I cannot tell; but you have certainly no right to concern yourself in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: mine. I must beg, therefore, to be importuned no further on the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: subject.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Not so hasty, if you please. I have by no means done. To all the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: objections I have already urged I have still another to add. I am no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister’s infamous
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: elopement. I know it all; that the young man’s marrying her was a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: patched-up business, at the expense of your father and uncle. And is
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _such_ a girl to be my nephew’s sister? Is _her_ husband, who is the son
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of his late father’s steward, to be his brother? Heaven and earth!--of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: what are you thinking? Are the shades of Pemberley to be thus polluted?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You can _now_ have nothing further to say,” she resentfully answered.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You have insulted me, in every possible method. I must beg to return to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the house.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: And she rose as she spoke. Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: back. Her Ladyship was highly incensed.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You have no regard, then, for the honour and credit of my nephew!
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Unfeeling, selfish girl! Do you not consider that a connection with you
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Lady Catherine, I have nothing further to say. You know my sentiments.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You are then resolved to have him?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I have said no such thing. I am only resolved to act in that manner,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which will, in my own opinion, constitute my happiness, without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reference to _you_, or to any person so wholly unconnected with me.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “It is well. You refuse, then, to oblige me. You refuse to obey the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: claims of duty, honour, and gratitude. You are determined to ruin him in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the opinion of all his friends, and make him the contempt of the world.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elizabeth, “has any
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: possible claim on me, in the present instance. No principle of either
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: would be violated by my marriage with Mr. Darcy. And with regard to the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resentment of his family, or the indignation of the world, if the former
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _were_ excited by his marrying me, it would not give me one moment’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: concern--and the world in general would have too much sense to join in

text: the scorn.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth into could not be easily overcome; nor could she for many
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hours learn to think of it less than incessantly. Lady Catherine, it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: appeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with Mr.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Darcy. It was a rational scheme, to be sure! but from what the report of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: till she recollected that _his_ being the intimate friend of Bingley,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and _her_ being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the idea. She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sister must bring them more frequently together. And her neighbours at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lucas Lodge, therefore, (for through their communication with the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collinses, the report, she concluded, had reached Lady Catherine,) had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only set _that_ down as almost certain and immediate which _she_ had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: looked forward to as possible at some future time.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: In revolving Lady Catherine’s expressions, however, she could not help
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in this interference. From what she had said of her resolution to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prevent the marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: application to her nephew; and how he might take a similar
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: representation of the evils attached to a connection with her she dared
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: not pronounce. She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: aunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: that he thought much higher of her Ladyship than _she_ could do; and it
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was certain, that in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with _one_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: address him on his weakest side. With his notions of dignity, he would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: probably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: If he had been wavering before, as to what he should do, which had often
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: seemed likely, the advice and entreaty of so near a relation might

text: I should be so reasonable as to admit it! But I wonder how long you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _would_ have gone on, if you had been left to yourself. I wonder when
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you _would_ have spoken if I had not asked you! My resolution of
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much_, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: subject? This will never do.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “You need not distress yourself. The moral will be perfectly fair. Lady
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Catherine’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: removing all my doubts. I am not indebted for my present happiness to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: your eager desire of expressing your gratitude. I was not in a humour to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: wait for an opening of yours. My aunt’s intelligence had given me hope,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and I was determined at once to know everything.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for she loves to be of use. But tell me, what did you come down to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Netherfield for? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed?
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: or had you intended any more serious consequences?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “My real purpose was to see _you_, and to judge, if I could, whether I
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: might ever hope to make you love me. My avowed one, or what I avowed to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: myself, was to see whether your sister was still partial to Bingley, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: befall her?”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I am more likely to want time than courage, Elizabeth. But it ought to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be done; and if you will give me a sheet of paper it shall be done
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: directly.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you, and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did. But
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: long letter; but now, having _that_ to communicate which she knew would
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: follows:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: truth, I was too cross to write. You supposed more than really existed.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: But _now_ suppose as much as you choose; give a loose to your fancy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: indulge your imagination in every possible flight which the subject will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: afford, and unless you believe me actually married, you cannot greatly
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: err. You must write again very soon, and praise him a great deal more
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: than you did in your last. I thank you again and again, for not going to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the Lakes. How could I be so silly as to wish it! Your idea of the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ponies is delightful. We will go round the park every day. I am the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: happiest creature in the world. Perhaps other people have said so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: before, but no one with such justice. I am happier even than Jane; she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: only smiles, I laugh. Mr. Darcy sends you all the love in the world that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: can be spared from me. You are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Yours,” etc.

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I must trouble you once more for congratulations. Elizabeth will
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: you can. But, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew. He has
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother on his approaching
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere. She wrote even to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: professions of regard. Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as sincere as her brother’s in sending it. Four sides of paper were
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: being loved by her sister.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge. The reason of this
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sudden removal was soon evident. Lady Catherine had been rendered so
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew’s letter, that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the storm was blown over. At such a moment, the arrival of her friend
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: husband. He bore it, however, with admirable calmness. He could even
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: listen to Sir William Lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: meeting frequently at St. James’s, with very decent composure. If he did
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shrug his shoulders, it was not till Sir William was out of sight.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mrs. Philips’s vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: forbearance; and though Mrs. Philips, as well as her sister, stood in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever she _did_ speak, she must be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: vulgar. Nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all likely to make her more elegant. Elizabeth did all she could to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: keep him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so
title: Pride and Prejudice

title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: rid of her two most deserving daughters. With what delighted pride she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: guessed. I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and invariably silly.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drew him oftener from home than anything else could do. He delighted in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth. So near
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: a vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: _his_ easy temper, or _her_ affectionate heart. The darling wish of his
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sisters was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to Derbyshire; and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her two elder sisters. In society so superior to what she had generally
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: known, her improvement was great. She was not of so ungovernable a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: temper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia’s example, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: ignorant, and less insipid. From the further disadvantage of Lydia’s
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: society she was of course carefully kept; and though Mrs. Wickham
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Mary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mrs. Bennet’s being quite
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: unable to sit alone. Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters’ beauty and her own,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much reluctance.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: the marriage of her sisters. He bore with philosophy the conviction that
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: prevailed on to make his fortune. The congratulatory letter which
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Elizabeth received from Lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished. The
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: letter was to this effect:--
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: /* “My dear Lizzy, */
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “I wish you joy. If you love Mr. Darcy half so well as I do my dear
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Wickham, you must be very happy. It is a great comfort to have you
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: think of us. I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: upon without some help. Any place would do of about three or four
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: if you had rather not.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: “Yours,” etc.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: frequently sent them. It had always been evident to her that such an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: discharging their bills. Their manner of living, even when the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: extreme. They were always moving from place to place in quest of a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: cheap situation, and always spending more than they ought. His affection
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: reputation which her marriage had given her. Though Darcy could never
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: receive _him_ at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: further in his profession. Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to _talk_
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: of giving them a hint to be gone.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to Elizabeth.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see. They were able to love each
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: other, even as well as they intended. Georgiana had the highest opinion
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive manner of
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: talking to her brother. He, who had always inspired in herself a respect
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: pleasantry. Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her way. By Elizabeth’s instructions she began to comprehend that a
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: woman may take liberties with her husband, which a brother will not
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: all intercourse was at an end. But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation;
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: With the Gardiners they were always on the most intimate terms. Darcy,
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing
title: Pride and Prejudice

text: her into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
